Beat the villain into Submission with a ton of low cost events. And when you've had enough, Carol will Go Down Swinging for an extra 4 damage only to Make The Call and get her back in the same round or the following round. The hits just keep on Coming with these two working together with a little help using Jessica's apartment.

name: Doctor van Dyne
description_md:
Tweaked and updated version of the Healer Wasp deck originally shared here: https://marvelcdb.com/deck/view/311885?deck_name=Wasp-Heal%20Bot

Includes Ingenuity because Nadia can totally make great use of that. Slightly overstuffed at 43 cards but Assess the Situation really makes the deck breeze right through itself. Just with a couple quick tests via the drawer, once the deck begins slimming down you see the heal events over and over and over and you have a hand size of almost permanently 7-9 cards. I'd anticipate in multiplayer that defend exhausts and low HP would just be a thing of the past.

Meditation is in place of Power of Protection because it's technically more efficient, at the cost of giving up on the alter ego ability, which may or may not hurt (it's highly likely any given hand may have too many cards usable for resources because there's not anything left worth healing). Power of Protection can easily be swapped back in, however, if you want the alter ability to always be on.

Definitely not a solo deck, you'll almost certainly get smashed by the scheme.

name: Rayo repulsor
description_md:
Mazo basado para aguantar 2 ó 3 turnos en alter ego e ir preparando mesa poniendo en juego las tecnologías de Iron Man.
Intentamos ser agresivos con el Mulligan para poner en juego "Bajo Vigilancia" o "No Tan Deprisa", eso nos da un par de turnos sin necesitar cambiar a Iron Man.
Una vez tengamos 3 ó 4 tecnologías en juego, pasamos a nuestro estado de Heroe. En este mazo la mayoría de cartas son de energía y esto potencia la carta "Rayo Repulsor" la cuál jugáremos cada vez que este en nuestro poder, puesto que haremos una media de 8 de daño cada vez que la utilicemos.
La carta "Consciencia Mejorada" la utilizaremos para gastar uno de sus tres recursos y pasar al estado aéreo y beneficiarnos tanto de las tecnologías que se aprovechan de ello como principalmente de "Rayo Repulsor"
Este mazo está hecho con cartas de hasta Wave3, por lo que se podría intentar mejorar con cartas más actuales, aunque tal y como está funciona perfectamente.

name: Brains & Brawn
description_md: Summary and Theme This deck combines the brains of Dr. Bruce Banner with the punishing brawn of the Hulk. I sacrificed some more efficient cards in order to be more thematic. For example, [Sonic Rifle](/card/20015) may work better in practice than [Concussive Blow](/card/05031), but let's be honest -- Hulk doesn't usually use guns. Likewise, [Meditation](/card/26036) represents Bruce's ability to manage the Hulk better. Mulligan To get your engine running, try to find [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091), [Helicarrier](/card/01092), and [Deft Focus](/card/16024). Since you will also be in alter-ego form, it may be helpful to find [Meditation](/card/26036) to help pay for these ([Meditation](/card/26036) can only be used in alter-ego form, so use it to pay for supports/upgrades; you can't use it to pay for any of the 20 hero action events). Remember, in addition to the usual mulligan, Bruce Banner can swap out 1 card. Lesser priorities would include [Counterintelligence](/card/08017), [Boundless Rage](/card/10009), [Immovable Object](/card/10010), [Beat Cop](/card/10029), and [Under Surveillance](/card/06031). Strategy Damage is dealt via allies (especially [Wiccan](/card/15011)), [Crushing Blow](/card/10002), [Hulk Smash](/card/10003), [Thunderclap](/card/10005), and [Beat Cop](/card/10029). Thwarting is accomplished via allies, [Clear the Area](/card/04049), [Concussive Blow](/card/05031), [Lay Down the Law](/card/12031), [Beat Cop](/card/10029), and [Counterintelligence](/card/08017). Don't be afraid to go into alter-ego mode in order to recover, especially if the villain is confused from a [Concussive Blow](/card/05031) and/or you can play [Lay Down the Law](/card/12031) as you do so. Manage threat, and occasionally make a big attack ([Hulk Smash](/card/10003) + [Boundless Rage](/card/10009) = 14 damage!

Use [Wong](/card/09002) and [Inspiring Presence](/card/10030) to heal ally/hero who use [Clarity of Purpose](/card/31029). Spend an ally or two early without an issue as they answer [Make the Call](/card/01071).

name: Exploding big allies and chaos magic
description_md:
The combo

————————-

1- Prepare combo with [Spiritual Meditation](/card/15019), the alter ego power and [The Sorcerer Supreme](/card/09026)

2- Cheat play a big ally with [Sneak Attack](/card/23017), [Summoning Spell](/card/21055) or [Chaos Magic](/card/15003)

3- Attack/Threat with allies. And again with [Command Team](/card/23016)

4- Explode the ally with [Go Down Swinging](/card/23019)

5- Revive it with [Rapid Response](/card/08031)

What about the witch?

————————————————————-

The witch could be in defense, especially with [Scarlet Witch's Crest](/card/15009)

You can push for draw with [Hex Bolt](/card/15004) and still be able to do a combo turn. [Molecular Decay](/card/15005) should be use on big minions. Going to Alter ego and Threat/Recover should work to with low threat ennemy.

If not able to have a combo turn, do preparation; [The Sorcerer Supreme](/card/09026), [Command Team](/card/23016), [Agatha Harkness](/card/15007), [Scarlet Witch's Crest](/card/15009)

Other Synergy

————————————-


- [Captain America](/card/03001a) is great target to [Chaos Magic](/card/15003) or [Summoning Spell](/card/21055) and could live more than one turn. Explode him later in this case

- [Black Panther](/card/01040a)is especially good to get his exploding card with the response abilty; onf combo piece less to set.

name: Powolne ogrywanie S03E12 - Gamora
description_md:
**Powolne ogrywanie S03E12 - Gamora (karty do Gamora )**

Cześć, jestem casualowym graczem, który lubi sobie dość wolno ogrywać wszystko testując (nawet troszkę na siłę) mając "w poważaniu" tempo wydawania dodatków przez FFG ;) Standardowo testuje na solo na 5 scenariuszach z kampanii grając jednak jako standalone na expercie z losowymi modular setami.

Lecimy dalej, nadszedł czas na kolejny pakiecik. [Star-Lord](/card/17001a) nie wyglądał jakby miał stać się moim ulubieńcem, a stał się. Gamora również nie wyglądała mi jakoś super ciekawie... i w sumie to nie jest. Nie jest to może najsłabszy wydany do tego momentu guardian, ale chyba najmniej fajnie mi się nią grało i wypada pod tym względem nawet gorzej od [Groot](/card/16001a). A czy jest silna? przekonajmy się.

Mechanika Gamory opiera się na eventach. To czym się wyróżnia to dodatkowe możliwości w deckbuildingu - możemy dorzucić dodatkowe 6 atk/thw eventów z dowolnego aspektu. Dodatkowo mamy staty 2/2/2 + zdolność hero zadające dodatkowo 1 dmg za pierwszy Thw event zagrany w fazie i zdjęcie 1 zagrożenia za pierwszy atk event w fazie. Wszystko to czyni nas naprawdę wszechstronną postać. Przynajmniej na piewszy rzut oka. 

Nic więc dziwnego, że jej zestaw kart bohaterskich to przede wszystkim... 
- thw/atk eventy.

  - Mamy zestaw "dużych eventów" w postaci [Decisive Blow](/card/18006) i [Forward Momentum](/card/18007), które są bazowo już poprawnymi kartami, ale mają dodatkowo zwiększoną siłę gdy zagraliśmy odpowiedni event przed ich zagraniem. Więc od razu widzimy jak autorzy chcą, by budować Gamorę. Musimy mieć raz dużo thw/atk eventów jak i stosunkowo tanich, by być w stanie zagrywać oba rodzaje w 1 turze, by wyciągnąć najwięcej value z naszej zabójczyni.
 - No i mamy zestaw "małych eventów", czyli [Acrobatic Move](/card/18003) i [Set the Pace](/card/18005), które są przede wszystkim eventami za 0, czyli tanimi aktywatorami "dużych eventów". Set the pace jest troszkę biedne.. Thw jest w Marvelu bardziej cenione niż atak, więc ten punkt mniej niby nie powinien szczególnie dziwić, ale zagrywając go naprawdę nie czuć dużego wpływu na grę. Acrobatic Move jest za to świetny - tani, uniwersalny, odpala dodatkowa [Gamora's Sword](/card/18010). 
 - ostatni i chyba najlepszy i najfajniejszy jest [Crosscounter](/card/18004). Za 1 zasób prewencja 3 obrażeń, zadane 1 obrażenia i usunięcie 1 zagrożenia już samo w sobie jest spoko, ale to ile ma dodakowych synergii to już jest miód. Jest to de facto defensywny event, ale ma trait "attack" i "thwart" przez to dalej możemy go znaleźć ze zdolności Alter-ego czy [Nebula](/card/18002), zagrywamy ją w innej fazie niż standardowe eventy przez co odpalamy pasywkę z Hero dodatkowy raz, odpala też [Gamora's Sword](/card/18010). Naprawdę robi robotę.
- Eventy zajmują dokładnie 2/3 puli kart bohaterskich najniebezpieczniejszej kobiety, poza tym za dużo nie mamy. I tu wychodzi kolejna cecha Gamory - mało się buduje, więc jesteśmy silni na początku, ale mało rośniemy w siłę w ciągu gry. 
 - Mamy 2x do bólu standardowych generatorów zasobów wspierających główną mechanikę bohatera w postaci [Keen Instincts](/card/18009)
 - [Nebula](/card/18002) poza plot twistem twórców w postaci [Nebula](/card/18026), jest wręcz genialna. Staty 2/2 za 2 zasoby to już coś fajnego, a że dobieramy kartę to tak jakby kosztuje 1 zasób więc jeszcze fajniej, a to, że dobieramy akurat ten event który potrzebujemy to już najfajniej na świecie.
 - Wspomniany wielokrotnie [Gamora's Sword](/card/18010) jest świetny, co za rzadko mi się zdarza mówić o upgradach za 3 zasoby. Tym samym zawsze staram się go zagrywać jak tylko mogę sobie na to pozwolić. Przez całą grę wbije całkiem solidną dawkę obrażeń, jako że wydarzeń od ataku mamy mnóstwo, a mieczyk nie ma ograniczeń. Dwa, że te "pingi" za 1 są mocno elastyczne. Dobijanie minionów, zdejmowania tougha, omijanie retaliate itp.
 - [Conditioning Room](/card/18008) dobiera nam kartę z discardu, której nawet nie możemy wybrać, bo zawsze to atk/thw event 1wszy od dołu. W porównaniu do innych dobierajek innych postaci nie takie fajne, ale naprawdę lubię dodatkowe leczenie postaci. Im więcej grałem tym bardziej się do niego przekonywałem.

I to tyle jeśli chodzi o karty wbudowane, lecimy z preconem. A precon jest no... jakby to powiedzieć... Gamora ma synergię z zagrywaniem atk/thw i eventów, ma u siebie pełno atk/thw eventów więc w jej preconnie mamy... no... pełno thw/atk eventów ;) I w zasadzie ciężko coś tu powiedzieć, bo jej talia to właściwie zlepek losowych wydarzeń i można je dowolnie wymieniać i jakoś to będzie, więc ciężko coś mądrego powiedzieć w kwestii ulepszania.

- z ataków proponowanych przez twórców mamy:
 - [Clobber](/card/18012) to taki [Haymaker](/card/01087) z twistem. Jak zagramy go jako pierwszego wraca nam na rękę, więc nie jako znowu kosztuje 1 zasób mniej, dwa że potencjalnie możemy zagrać go ponownie i łącznie mamy wtedy 6 za 4 zasoby, czyli lepszy jakby [Uppercut](/card/01054). Więc cudów nie ma, ale 2x odpalimy przy tym [Gamora's Sword](/card/18010) przez swoją budowe jest dość elastyczny, jest ok. Po prostu ok.
 - reprint [Uppercut](/card/01054) - hehe. nie. 
 - [First Hit](/card/18015) i tutaj trochę rozumiem i nie rozumiem twórców. Rozumiem, że zamysł jest taki, żeby wsadzić atk z protekcji by pokazać, że można i, że ten dodatkowa opcja deckbuildingu po coś jest. Nie rozumiem, bo jednak to agresja jest królem atk i eventów, a dostajemy nową kartę do protekcji no cóż. Jak to u protekcji ataki są ciupkę droższe, 2 atk za 1 zasób szału nie robi. W wersji na miniony, czyli efekt [Nova](/card/05012) jak znajdzie target już lepiej. Jeśli znajdzie target (w sensie który zginie, przed możliwością ataku).

- Eventów stricte od zdejmowania zagrożeń już mamy mniej, tylko [Impede](/card/18016) która oczywiście jest justicową wersją [Clobber](/card/18012). I nic dodać nic ująć.

- Dodatkowo mamy jeszcze [Hit and Run](/card/18020) która łączy w sobie zdejmowanie zagrożenia i atak. Drogi w stosunko do tego co robi, ale łączy sobie atk i thw event i ma oba traity, więc wszystkie synergie się bawią. Więc na Gamorze całkiem, całkiem się sprawuje.

- Sojuszników jak to zwykle w preconie mamy mniej niż to nam do szczęścia potrzebne. U nas tylko w 2 sztukach:
 - [Drax](/card/18019) to przykład klasycznej karty, która ma lepsze cyferki za to ograniczenie. Ograniczeniem jest to, że nie możemy atakować minionów. I jak dla mnie spoko. To nie ograniczenie w stylu Hulka, gdzie musimy dużo zainwestować, a i tak koniec końców liczyć na RNG. Tutaj wiemy co dostajemy, w tym co robi - czyli laniu złola - jest naprawdy ok. Dla mnie ok, jak to do tej pory wszyscy basic sojusznicy z paczki GOTG.
 - Z [Angela](/card/18011) to zależy. Głównie na co gramy. Z zabijaniem minionów nie mamy problemów, więc w naszym decku spisuje się jak najbardziej. Tylko trochę zależy na co gramy. Zdarzyła mi się gra na [Ultron](/card/01135) z Legion of Hydra, gdzie w ogóle nie chciałem jej zagrywać.

- Co my tamy jeszcze mamy... jakieś takie zapychajki...
 - [Plan of Attack](/card/18013) jest ok, Mamy tyle tych ataków, że ani razu nie spudłowałem, nawet zagrywając w wersji z Hero. Z drugiej strony... Ani razu też za bardzo mi tyłka nie uratował doborem tego wydarzenia, więc póki co... ani ziębi ani grzeje.
 - [Combat Training](/card/01057) i [Godslayer](/card/18018) to dość dziwne wyboru jako, że opieramy się na eventach. Na początku myślałem, że twórcy po prostu starają się zrobić z nas jakąś super-agresywną bestią do rushowania złoli i mamy iść wszystkimi zasobami w przeciwnika, tylko, że w praktyce to średnio działa... z defensywą u nas krótko więc nie ustaniemy za długo, nie jesteśmy Hulkiem. A jak chcemy grać trochę wolniej to wyczerpuje się częściej w innych celach by ładować w siebie drogie upgrady.

No i tyle. Przechodzimy do naprawiania. Tutaj właściwie trochę dziwnie się czuje, bo równie dobrze moglibyśmy wywalić wszystkie eventy i dać je po prostu w dowolnej konfiguracji jakiej chcemy. Nie pasuje mi tu zdecydowanie jedynie [First Hit](/card/18015) oraz [Uppercut](/card/01054). Zostawiłem 1 kopię tylko [Plan of Attack](/card/18013). Dodatkowo usunąłem zbędne moim zdaniem karty od basic ataku czyli [Godslayer](/card/18018) oraz [Combat Training](/card/01057). Łącznie mamy tym samym 10 kart do zagodospadowania.

 - Zaczynamy od uzupełnienia eventów. IMO mamy wystarczającą siłe w thwortowaniu - [Impede](/card/18016) którego od biedy możemy użyć podwójnie, [Hit and Run](/card/18020) w połączeniu z pasywką Gamory oraz jej bazowymi 2 thw w grze solo wystarczy nam do szczęścia. Możemy zainwestować w rzeczy typowo owensywne.

  - lubimy tanie eventy, a co jest ofensywnym tanim eventem do którego zwykle nie mamy dostępu w agresji? Ano [Turn the Tide](/card/15015). z naszym mieczykiem to 4 dmg za 0. Jest moc.

  - 2gim upgradem jest rzadko widziane w solo [Get Over Here!](/card/06014). Oczywiście działa tylko na miniony więc nie jest cudowne zawsze. Normalnie ta karta jest meh, jednak tutaj to aktywator wszystkich dobrodziejstw. Z samym mieczykiem to 2 dmg za 0 więc już wartość ok. Dodatkowo aktywuje umiejętność Gamory + umożliwia wzmocnione [Forward Momentum](/card/18007).

- Naszą jedyną słabością jest nasza defensywa, więc najprościej - rozwiązać ją tanimi sojusznikami których w preconach zawsze mało. [Ironheart](/card/13018) oraz [Spider-Girl](/card/04040) są zawsze świetni. [Bug](/card/16040) trochę gorzej, bo jednak tak często nie będziemy atakować podstawowymi atakami, ale trochę można z niego wyciągnąć. Całość zamyka  nasz dzielny [Rocket Raccoon](/card/16019). Grzechem go nie brać gdy mamy do niego dostęp.

- Całość zamyka [Martial Prowess](/card/10018) jako kolejny generator do eventów, ale nie jest żadną kluczową kartą. Chcemy raczej zabijać szybko, niż zbroić się nie wiadomo jak. Jak czujemy że możemy przeciwnika szybko wykończyć - to robimy to. Tutaj karta do zagrania w wolnej chwili, jak czujemy że możemy się przeciągnąć itp.

I tak by wyglądał nasz deck. Szczerze samej Gamory, jej stylu gry jak i decku średnio polubiłem. Jej mechanika to po prostu rzucania eventów na pałe i czerpanie przy okazji z nich korzyści. Słaba nie jest, silna też nie. Ot ok postać. 

I to by było na tyle.

name: Thor -  God of Thunder
description_md: Let's start with that, that Thor is my **favourite** hero in the MCU, by far. I'm still fairly new to the game, and still a beginner in deckbuilding, yet I'm seeing some sparks already and am connecting the dots. I was really sad to see that Thor was so mutilated with a hand size of 5/4 (alter-ego/hero), yet I really wanted to make him work. I've played with the pre-constructed deck 3 times, lost 3 times and hated him, but then I've stumbled upon Team-Covenant's very low curve deck and then I've realised that's the problem - the precon had way too many expensive cards and I was stuck multiple times with a dead hand, able to play 1 or even sometimes 0 cards. This is a (in my opinion) a way better and a waaaay more consistent version of Team Covenant's Thor deck https://marvelcdb.com/decklist/view/2250/thor-we-were-swingin-1.0 which included some very counter-intuitive and counter-kit cards, below is my write-up: Let's start by his basic abilities: in **alter-ego** he can summon his beloved hammer Mjolnir (which you should immediately see as an additional resource) every round, in **hero** form when he engages a minion, he draws 2 cards with a limit once per phase. Let that sink in, once **per phase**... I've immediately observed that basically if he can engage a minion in hero phase he basically has a hand size of 6 (not including [Asgard](/card/06007)), if you get lucky in the Villain phase you make that 8 - whopping 8 cards at the start of the round, that's sick! So with the staple cards he should have - [Angela](/card/25015), [Looking for Trouble](/card/16043), and his kit's [Defender of the Nine Realms](/card/06003) you make sure you engage that minion almost every turn and have an **ater-ego** form hand size in **hero form**. Reasons why I got rid of TC's cards: - second copy of [Combat Training](/card/01057) - I don't even know why would somebody include more than 1 copy of that card, this should be self-explanatory, but let's explain that - if you have that in play, the second copy is a dead card, and even if you somehow discard the first one, because you needed it for other reasons, with Thor's deck-cycling ability, you'll have it fast back in your hands. Yes, it's a , so it does work with [Hulk](/card/01050) and [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019), but this definitely is not a reason to include a dead card. - another **almost**-dead card (and same symbol card) is a [Counterattack](/card/08030), even though you face-tank many attacks with Thor, it's not worth to give him such a card, as we want to get as close to a **40** cards deck as possible, this card does not deserve the spot, but I would consider including a 1 copy for some attack heavy Villains, like VG/Thanos/Crossbones,etc. - [Tigra](/card/01051) - initially I've played with her for like 15 games, and I've used her maybe once, mostly she's too expensive to play and/or we lack the ally spot to put her in as Thor has better allies to use, for example: [Angela](/card/18011), [Bug](/card/16040), [Lady Sif](/card/06002), [Throg](/card/25014), [Valkyrie](/card/06012), let's not mention she's a symbol that really does not work with [Hulk](/card/01050), who with the amount of and in this deck might be used as an attacker or just a tank, your call - I've had a lot of luck with both versions. - [Get Over Here!](/card/06014) - this card is completely dead in singleplayer and even in multiplayer we already have a lot of ways to engage minions that this card probably has no space here, although I could consider putting it in in some really-minion heavy encounter sets that could swarm other players. Once we have that down, I'll explain the inclusions: - [Angela](/card/18011) - beats me why it was not included in most popular Thor's deck on mcdb - imo it's a staple, I'd say it could even be in his kit as one of the 1/15 hero cards, yet they made it an aggression card to work with Valyrie hero. - [Hall of Heroes](/card/06017) - I could basically copy above card's explanation, when hero's kit is based on defeating minions and we have a card that let's us draw 3 cards in **alter-ego** every 3 defeated minions - that's a staple, works perfectly with Thor's kit. - [Looking for Trouble](/card/16043) - Those are basically 3 more copies of [Defender of the Nine Realms](/card/06003), as the only thing that Thor struggles with is threat mitigation, we have to fight it as well as we can, additionally it works with Thor's kit perfectly, on top of that it has a symbol - it's perfect for other cards from this deck - [Hulk](/card/01050) and [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019). I'll say this again, but not in vain, this is a **perfect** Thor card. - [Throg](/card/25014) - it's basically a 2 cost minions that almost always has the tough status, as we want to be engaged with a minion at the start of every hero phase, it's almost a guarantee to have a 2 cost very good tank. - [Bug](/card/16040) - this ally helps us with anything we can't handle, for the most of the time it will be pinging those schemes for 1 every turn, then we attack, it heals, you get the gist. - [Chase Them Down](/card/01052) - additional copy of that to help with that threat mitigation. Cards to consider for the future: - [Down Time](/card/05033) - I don't have Ms.Marvel nor Phoenix, so I have not used that, but I can see this card being useful, sometimes you want to come back to Odinson form, call that hammer and heal, that would ensure you heal for 2 more. I'm seeing this card as useful in his kit, not sure how much though, will update in the future. - ["Bring It!"](/card/19030) - I also don't have Drax Hero Pack, but this card looks like an auto-include, as Thor you can have 1-2 and sometimes 3 minions engaged with you, that's up to 3 more cards to draw and the card itself let's us basically cycle itself (if we have at least 1 minion engaged with us, which we'll probably have) making it a deck with 3 less cards, and the lesser the better - you'll see your hero cards more often, and they are your strongest ones. **Update**: after getting Drax and this card to my collection I immediatelly added it and I have to say it's definitely a staple, works great in this deck for the reason described above. - [Gatekeeper](/card/32044) - If you would have any problem with threat while playing solo, you could consider playing this card, for 0 cost and +2 health to a minion (2 health minions still can be one-shotted with [Mjolnir](/card/06009) and [Combat Training](/card/01057)) it takes care of that 4 threat. However, I would not run that card too often. Let me know if you want some more write up, for example on the play-style/mulligans as I have not touched those at all.

name: Doctor Strange Wong x Cosmo - Wosmo Protection
description_md: *"Wong. Just Wong? Like Adele? Or Aristotle. Drake, Bono, Eminem…" - Dr. Steven Strange: Doctor Strange*. And I would add *"Cosmo. Just Cosmo? Like Wong?..."* Before we go through the deck and everyone starts to debate about how illegal is to play [Cosmo](/card/17020) + *Invocation* deck combo, please see below a question sent to **FFG**; "Is Doctor Strange's Invocation deck a legal target for Cosmo's ability?" Michael Boggs himself answered, "Yes, Doctor Strange's Invocation deck (along with any non-villain or non-main scheme deck, such as Red Skull's side-scheme deck) is a legal target for Cosmo's ability. Thanks, Michael Boggs" Following up on this, [Doctor Strange](/card/09001a) is simply broken... The deck is a *Stun/Confuse* deathtrap for any Villain. Effortlessly going through any dangers. **Wosmo magic** You will want to have [Wong](/card/09002) and [Cosmo](/card/17020) on the board all the time. Treat them as permanent support cards. With [Wong](/card/09002), [Cosmo](/card/17020) and [Stephen Strange](/card/09001b)'s *Natural Talent* you have 3 ways to change the top card of the *Invocation deck*. As a bonus, [Wong](/card/09002) can heal you in the cases where you don't need him to change the top card of the *Invocation deck*, and [Cosmo](/card/17020) will be chipping in with *Tough* removals, 1x *Thwart* or 1x damage (2x damage with [Sidearm](/card/23035)) every time you use it. Attacking *Sidearm* to *Cosmo* is important, as it will grant him *Ranged*, so the *Retaliate* keyword will be ignored for his attacks. [Med Team](/card/01080) and [The Night Nurse](/card/09019) are in this deck to heal up [Wong](/card/09002) and [Cosmo](/card/17020) when needed, not [Doctor Strange](/card/09001a) (unless really necessary). [Iron Fist](/card/09014) is just chilling there to throw in the occasional stun and take a hit for you if needed. **The rest of the deck** [Spiritual Meditation](/card/15019) will provide you with more draw-power and [Ever Vigilant](/card/17030) and [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016) will allow you to play multiple invocation cards while removing 2 threat or healing for 2 respectively. [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091) combined with [The Sorcerer Supreme](/card/09026) and [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) will make your hand size a permanent 8 regardless if you are in *Hero* or *Alter-Ego* form. And [Protective Ward](/card/09007) will take care of any treachery cards you draw, so the +1 encounter card cost for [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) won't affect you as much (if at all). [Forcefield Generator](/card/31019) is there to simply soak up damage for you, so you don't have to worry *IF* for some very *Strange* reason the *Villain* is not stunned in this round. Very straightforward deck to play with a lot of **everything** you can ever wish for packed in it.

name: Black Widow Always Prepared for Justice
description_md:
*At Some Point, We All Have To Choose Between What The World Wants You To Be And Who You Are.” - Black Widow: Black Widow*

Everything is in *Mission Preparation* mode. I love playing [Black Widow](/card/08001a). Her mechanics are cool and exciting to execute.

With this deck, you will spend a lot of time in your *Alter-Ego* form. Hense why [Crew Quarters](/card/20029) and [Agent 13](/card/27046) are included. Even if you flip to *[Natasha Romanoff](/card/08001b)* after you have used one of [Black Widow](/card/08001a)'s basic powers, you can heal, and you can re-ready [Safe House #29](/card/08005) allowing you to add two ***PREPARATION *** cards from your discard pile to your hand.

Being in *Alter-Ego* is no problem at all as the *Thwart* power of the deck is ridiculous. [Counterintelligence](/card/08017) will more often than not leave the *Villain* with *Scheming* for close to **0**. On top of that, you can play [Covert Ops](/card/08003) even in *Alter-Ego*. Your *Allies* will take care of the rest of the *threats* (if there is any left) and will deal some damage to the bad guy. On top of that, [Agent 13](/card/27046) will allow you to play [Safe House #29](/card/08005) twice in one turn, getting all the *Prep* cards you will need from your discard pile. As caviar, With this deck built I have always played [Winter Soldier](/card/08002) for free.

While you are in *Hero* form, thanks to *Widowmaker* you will do a lot of damage to the *Villain* over time. [Attacrobatics](/card/08006), [Spycraft](/card/08018), [Widow's Bite](/card/08010), [Spycraft](/card/08018) and [Target Acquired](/card/08024) are all cards you can activate during the *Villain* phase, and some of them multiple times. Each *Preparation* card activation will deal 1 damage to an enemy, and you will be activating loads of them each phase.

Also, once you have [Synth-Suit](/card/08009) on the board, don't forget to defence against the *Villain's* attack, as triggering any of the prep cards will allow you to ready [Black Widow](/card/08001a) and you will take 3 less damage for this attack (4 with *Symbiote Suit*).

[Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) is great in this deck because; 1st - combined with [Synth-Suit](/card/08009) will give you 4 DEF in total. 2nd - extra hand size allow you to play more **Prep** cards. 3rd - you have 5 cards in the deck to help you get rid of/or change the *treachery* card ([Grappling Hook](/card/08008) and [Spycraft](/card/08018)).

Once you have all 10 permanent *Upgrades* and *Supports* on the board, you will enjoy a smooth journey to your win.

**Side note**

The deck has only 10 permanent *Upgrades* and *Supports*, which means you are cycling through 30 cards after set-up. Combining [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091), [Espionage](/card/08033), [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) and *Mission Prep* makes the draw-power of the deck really big. But if you want a slimmer deck to play with, you can exchange 1 copy of [Spycraft](/card/08018) and 2 copies of [Counterintelligence](/card/08017) for [Endurance](/card/05023), [Down Time](/card/05033) and [Team-Building Exercise](/card/12024) bringing the recycling cards down to 27.

name: Quicksilver Always be Ready for Protection
description_md:
*"You didn't see that coming?" - Quicksilver: Avengers: Age of Ultron*

When I first glanced at [Quicksilver](/card/14001a), I didn't think I would love playing him. Then I built myself a *Protection* deck and maaaan... it's so fun to play.

The whole deck is built around [Quicksilver](/card/14001a)'s *Super Speed* ability. As it is **once per phase**, you can defend every turn and when you do so, you trigger loads of stuff happening to the *bad guys*.

Because 4 DEF (after set-up) might not be always enough to block all the damage, I have included 3x [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) to reflect any excess damage. 

[Black Widow](/card/01075) and [Nova](/card/05012) in this deck are treated as support cards. You get them out and you use their abilities. If you are really desperate, then you can use one of them to block a punch for you as well.

[Jocasta](/card/26013) is there to pick up your [Desperate Defense](/card/09015) from the discard pile and hold it for you until you need it. This way you can defend twice during the *Villain* phase and still be ready for game during the *Players* phase. [Nerves of Steel](/card/14017) only purpose is to let you play [Desperate Defense](/card/09015) for free.

[Bait and Switch](/card/15030) is just perfect for the deck as it will remove 4 threats from a scheme and on top of that it will trigger all of your *upgrades* abilities.

The deck does not have a built-in treachery interrupt, and because the chance is higher to get one thanks to [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191), [Get Behind Me!](/card/01078) will prevent this treachery from executing and will give you what want, another way for you to defence against the *Villain*'s attack.

At the same time, [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) will allow you to play [Dauntless](/card/16016) more securely and will provide you with a needed boost for your stats and hand size. Together with [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091) and [Unflappable](/card/09020) you will have 8 cards hand every round.

The deck is not the easiest to execute, but really fun to play.

name: Spider-Man Minion Genius Aggression
description_md: *“Anyone can win a fight when the odds are easy! It’s when the going’s tough when there seems to be no chance – that’s when it counts.” – Spider-Man: Amazing Spider-Man #33* We all love our friendly neighbourhood *Spider-Man*. And we all know he doesn't do things in an easy way but in more fun and entertaining way. This deck is **very fun** and **not easy** to play, as the setup requires a lot of correct decisions. Because of the costly *Allies* and set-up cards, you will spend a lot of time in your Alter-Ego. [Meditation](/card/26036), [Ingenuity](/card/29027) and [Peter Parker](/card/01001b)'s Scientist ability will provide you with a lot of resources needed for your set-up and for your costly Allies. [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022) is an essential part of the *[Meditation](/card/26036)/Alter-Ego* action. As the deck is shallow on Thwart power, you will need all the help you can get from your Allies to stay in the game. The only built-in *Thwart* mechanism in the deck is [Spider-Tracer](/card/01007), which requires a *minion* to be in play. [Angela](/card/18011) will get you out a Minion. This will also get you a [Hall of Heroes](/card/06017) glory counter after the *minion* is defeated. [Melee](/card/05030) combined with [Honed Technique](/card/28017) will deal 6 damage to 2 enemies, so that's a fast and easy way to get rid of the minion you just got on the board and deal some damage to the *Villain* in the same time. [Smash the Problem](/card/25019) is another way to remove 4 *threat* for 1 cost after the set-up is completed. [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) will allow you to survive for longer and punch harder, and thanks to [Backflip](/card/01003) and [Enhanced Spider-Sense](/card/01004) the extra encounter card will not be big of an issue. Even after the entire set-up is on the table, [Meditation](/card/26036) will allow you to flip to *Alter-Ego*, play costly ally and heal. **The permanent Ally support** [Wolverine](/card/32041)'s ability to heal for 1 every turn means that if you get him early on the board, you can use him every so often to deal 6 damage (this includes the boosts of [Boot Camp](/card/13016), [Attack Trainig](/card/32043), and [Sidearm](/card/23035)) to a Minion or the Villain and thanks to [Sidearm](/card/23035) you will ignore *retaliate* and on top of that you already have *piercing*. Essentially you will treat [Wolverine](/card/32041) as a permanent upgrade which will be dealing a lot of fo damage over time. [Brawn](/card/10011) will help with the Thwart a little, while chipping away the Healt points of the bad guys. The rest of the Allies will not stay for long on the board and will help with Thwart and cards drawing power. The deck is built in a way where you can utilise [Black Cat](/card/01002)'s ability to its full potential. **Side note** Your **Starting hand** will preferably include at least one [Meditation](/card/26036) card and at least one (preferably 2) high-cost set-up cards.

name: Hulk SMASH with lots of Aggression
description_md: *"Hulk barely touched that! Hulk doesn't care about your stuff! Hulk is not sorry, Hulk is Hulk." - Hulk: Avengers Vol 2 #4* What would [Hulk](/card/10001a) say about this deck? Probably something like *"Grrr...whhh....aaaah...grr...whaagrrr...aaaaahggr...waah."* Basically, the deck is built with the maximum possible *Thwart* power without crippling [Hulk](/card/10001a)'s strong attributes. All cards which are not permanent *Support* or *Upgrade* have resource printed on them. You will spend at least a few turns in your *Alter-Ego* to do at least a part of the set-up for the deck. [Banner's Laboratory](/card/10008) and [Ingenuity](/card/29027) are desirable cards to start with. Because [Hulk](/card/10001a) has the amazing stat of 0 *Thwart*, the biggest problem for any [Hulk](/card/10001a) deck is always the *Scheme* accumulation. The core deck contains only one *Thwart* event which will remove 3 (5 if paid for with only) for 3 cost. This is very expensive and hard to utilise. [Looking for Trouble](/card/16043) is the ONLY *Aggression Thwart* event which has printed on and it has 0 cost. So, I had to build a deck in a way where I can utilise it. This means that every time you play it, you will be engaging with a *minion*, therefore, [Hall of Heroes](/card/06017) and [Hand Cannon](/card/16046) had to be included in the deck. Make sure you are not careless with your [Hand Cannon](/card/16046) charge counters, as you will probably need those to deal with a minion and transfer the excess damage to the *Villain*. [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019) is there so you can utilise any excessive cards you have while you are in *Hero* form. Don't forget that you can activate [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019) as many times as you attack with [Hulk](/card/10001a), and this deck has 5 cards to ready your *Hero*. (If you prefer you can exchange Jarnbjorn for [Plan B](/card/27024), or add Plan B to the deck) [Wolverine](/card/32041) with attached [Sidearm](/card/23035) will give you *piercing* and *ranged* to get rid of any tough status and to help you clear up minions. Thanks to his ability to heal every turn, you treat [Wolverine](/card/32041) as a permanent upgrade card which will be dealing a lot of damage over time. [Helicarrier](/card/01092) and [Quincarrier](/card/08023) will provide very needed resource. And [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091) and [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) will provide the necessary number of cards to make this deck playable. The extra *Encounter* card is a hanging threat, as the deck doesn't have a built-in mechanism to stop *Treachery* cards. **After set-up is completed** The rest of the cards are useful in different situations. More often than not, you can take advantage of both [Fluid Motion](/card/28016) cards. [Ingenuity](/card/29027) combined with [Banner's Laboratory](/card/10008) will allow you to play [Hand Cannon](/card/16046) for free, and you can also heal for 9 when you flip to *Alter-Ego*. This will also let you draw extra cards with [Hall of Heroes](/card/06017). The deck has a lot of punch and *overkill* power. The aim is to SMASH the *Villain* as quickly as possible, which is not that hard with the cards provided.

name: Iron Man Energy Aggression
description_md: *I’m sorry, Earth is closed today. You better pack it up and get outta here." - Tony Stark: Avengers: Infinity War* [Iron Man](/card/01029a) is a deck with a lot of built-in punch, but also not a lot of *Thwart* power. This deck is built in a way to take full advantage of your [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031). Because of that, you will have to let yourself be hit in order to remove *Threat*, [Crew Quarters](/card/20029) and [Down Time](/card/05033) will help you with your *recovery* as it will be needed. Your other *Threat* removals are [Snowguard](/card/29023) and [Iron Man](/card/01029a) himself via basic THW and [Mark V Helmet](/card/01037). With [Quincarrier](/card/08023) you will always have the required resource to gain the ***Aerial*** trait. [Pepper Potts](/card/01033) and [Martial Prowess](/card/10018) will allow you to play [Supersonic Punch](/card/01032) and deal **8** to an enemy. [Deft Focus](/card/16024) will allow you to play [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031) for free, and more often than not, I am hitting for **9** damage with this card. This way your attack events are taken care of. [Helicarrier](/card/01092) will reduce the cost of your expensive *Allies* to play. The resource generation power of the deck allows you to play 2-3 *Attack* events per phase, which works perfectly in combination with [Fluid Motion](/card/28016). As you will be inevitably encountering minions, and spending time in *Alter-Ego*, [Hall of Heroes](/card/06017) will come in handy to help you with bigger 'hand size' occasionally. The interesting card in this deck is [Bug](/card/16040). His ability to heal one hit point every time your *Hero* makes a basic attack can be utilised to the fullest in this deck. Attaching [Energy Spear](/card/22032) and [Sidearm](/card/23035) to *Bug* will boost his attack to 4 (5 with [Boot Camp](/card/13016)) and he will also gain *Ranged*. This means that every turn you do a basic attack with *Iron Man* you will be attacking with *Bug* as well. The deck is pretty interesting to play and execute. A lot of *RIGHT* decisions must be made for this deck to succeed. It is much more effective and easier to play it in *multiplayer*, but it works great in *single-player* as well.

name: Iron Man Energises Yondu's Leadership
description_md: *"In a world this vulnerable, we need something more powerful than any of us." Iron Man: Avengers: Age of Ultron* [Iron Man](/card/01029a) has always been one of my favourite decks to play. This deck is built around [Iron Man](/card/01029a)'s [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031) and [Supersonic Punch](/card/01032) and around *"...something more powerful than any of us"* - [Yondu](/card/17013). With [Quincarrier](/card/08023) you will always have the required resource to gain the ***Aerial*** trait. [Pepper Potts](/card/01033) and [Helicarrier](/card/01092) will allow you to play [Supersonic Punch](/card/01032) and deal **8** to an enemy. [Deft Focus](/card/16024) will allow you to play [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031) for free, and more often than not, I am hitting for **9** damage with this card. This way your attack events are taken care of. In case you really need to remove *Treat*, if needed, you can sacrifice your areal for one round and use [Quincarrier](/card/08023) to play [Push Ahead](/card/29018), as it requires resource to be played. In my experience with the deck, I had to do this very rarely. More often than not, [Push Ahead](/card/29018) was contributing towards my [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031), or it was used as a resource to get an *Ally* out. Speaking of *Allies*: We have the usual suspects in the line like [Hawkeye](/card/01066), whose vigilance will make any *minion* regret stepping on the board. [Kaluu](/card/21014), helping you get your hands on more copies of [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031) and [Supersonic Punch](/card/01032). [Stinger](/card/12014), doesn't care about the *Allies* limit and she is always happy to take a punch for you and is essentially free to get out when combined with [Avengers Tower](/card/03024). [White Tiger](/card/04099) will provide you with more cards in your hand so it pays for herself every time you play her and she has decent stats. And [Yondu](/card/17013) and [War Machine](/card/01030) where [War Machine](/card/01030) is really just a wild resource in this deck. Whenever possible I use it to gain the ***Aerial*** trait, instead of [Quincarrier](/card/08023). **[Yondu](/card/17013)** is the interesting one in this deck. He is the only **Ally** without the *AVENGER* trait, but in this deck, [Yondu](/card/17013) is an [Honorary Avenger](/card/03025). This way he can take advantage of the [Mighty Avengers](/card/21015) boost of **+1 ATK**. Of [Power Gloves](/card/12017) which will deal one additional damage to an *enemy* every phase *Yondu* attacks. Of [Sky Cycle](/card/04015) which will allow *Yondu* to attack twice every phase. And on top of that, [Inspired](/card/01074), [Laser Blaster](/card/17019) and [Sidearm](/card/23035) will provide additional **+1 ATK** each and *Overkill*. Combine this with *Yondu* being the only *Leadership Ally* who takes no consequential damage when he attacks and the fact that he has *Ranged*, makes *Yondu* a power no *Villain* wants to deal with. ***Let's break it down*** [Yondu](/card/17013) has 1 base ATK. Adding the *Support* and *Upgrade* cards +4 ATK in total makes 5 base ATK. [Sky Cycle](/card/04015) will allow you to do this attack twice, and each time you perform an attack, with [Power Gloves](/card/12017) you will deal 1 damage to an enemy. This is a total of **12 damage** per phase from *Yondu* only. Combine this with one [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031) and one [Supersonic Punch](/card/01032), plus another *Ally* or two, and you have dealt **30+** damage. The deck is very fun and easy to execute, and it can deal with any villain. **Side note** Always make sure you have at least one more *Ally* on the board together with [Yondu](/card/17013), as some *minions* and *treachery* cards will force you to defend with an *Ally*. And *Yondu* is not one to defend with. **Update:** Following advice from the comments, Lead from the Front is a great replacement for Push Ahead.

This deck was inspired by the Captain America stun lock deck, but just uses the same stun cards. Since Miles has more stunning cards I think it makes more sense to use him.

name: Ghost-Spider Aggression Solo Champions League Season 13 Roun
description_md:
This is the deck I played in Season 13 Round 2 of the Solo Champions League vs. Sinister Six. 

It's an aggression deck ,but really there are only 8 aggression cards.  Spider-Girl and Throg were mainly in there just to have some cheap allies in case I needed an emergency block.  I rarely played them.   Chase Them Down and Skilled Strike on the other hand... well, they are great with Ghost Spider. 

I used the Shock Knuckles for the Tech Upgrade and 3 copies of Defiance for my other aspect cards.

 I'm a big fan of Snowguard because she's so versatile.  I put 3 copies of Warrior of the Great Web mainly to help keep Spider-Man (Peter Parker) around for an extra turn and also to have one on Ghost Spider so she could play web-warrior cards while in Alter-Ego.  

Game 1 - Clean win in 7 rounds with 12 HP left between Ghost Spider and allies.

Game 2 - Clean win in 6 rounds with 11 HP left between Ghost Spider and allies

Game 3 - Win in 7 rounds with only 1 threat left on the main scheme keeping it from being clean.  Rather than going onto the next round to try to clean things up, I decided to end it there since I was going to be getting an extra encounter card from decking out.  I did have 16 HP left on Ghost Spider and allies though.

name: Ironheart - One Way or Another
description_md:
The plan is to let event cards handle most of the thwarting, while Riri deals damage. Allies should be able to fill in gaps in either as they come into play. 

Riri should focus on getting through her first form as quickly as possible so that [Agile Flight](/card/17029) comes into play. After that, use [One Way or Another](/card/22015) to bring in side schemes and bonus cards then drive threat down on both side schemes and the main scheme to benefit from [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047), [Clear the Area](/card/04049), [Justice Served](/card/22014) and [Chance Encounter](/card/26034) as well as [Pivotal Moment]. [Venom](/card/22013) will also benefit from a cleared off main scheme.

This should free up Riri to attack using her cards that allow her to ready.

name: Spider-Man Justice
description_md:
Spider Man Justice Deck

For solo play, Spider Man is solid but lacks a decent thwart. While Spider-Tracer is good and ideally protection deck really lets him shine, it doesn't work so well for solo play. This decks attempts to remedy that.

Both Daredevil and Jessica Jones are great allies that allow for some great thwarting potential. As they don't have forced response abilities, they can continue to be healed using first aid. Heroic Intuition is here on the off chance Spider Man is needed to thwart and an ally defends instead. Interrogation Room and Surveillance Team add to the general thwart here. 

Spider Man will still be defending for the most part and be staying in hero form. Due to this his deck needs to rely on events to attack. 2 haymakers allow for some more focused attack in addition to Daredevil's damage ability. 

Trying this vs the Protection deck and seeing which I like better.

0.4: Protection is trash, this justice is pretty solid, although somewhat dependent on allies. Didn't get a chance to thwart as my hero ever.

name: War Machine Running S.H.I.E.L.D. for 'Justice'
description_md:
*The future of air combat... Is it manned, or unmanned? I'll tell you, in my experience, no unmanned aerial vehicle will ever trump a pilot's instinct, his insight, that ability to look into a situation beyond the obvious and discern its outcome or a pilot's judgment. - James Rhodes: Iron Man*

[War Machine](/card/23001a) is a deck good against anything. I have always enjoyed playing this deck, but I wanted something with a little bit more interesting set-up. Something really fun and cool to execute *(...a pilot's instinct, ..., that ability to look into a situation beyond the obvious and discern its outcome...)*. 

This is why I built a very thematic deck around the *S.H.I.E.L.D.* archetype.

49 cards is a weird number to start with, but each card has its purpose in this deck.  *(I have summarised an option for trimming down the deck at the end of the description)*

All added cards with the exception of the resource cards and a few permanent *Support* and *Upgrades* cards are from the *S.H.I.E.L.D.* archetype.

This deck is built in a way where the cards interact with each other and do something useful every turn. 

[Government Liaison](/card/27054) will help you with setting up your deck and getting out those costly *Allies*. Later on, you can use it to utilise [Dum Dum Dugan](/card/27047), [Global Logistics](/card/27043) and [Homeland Intervention](/card/27042) to their full potential and you can utilise [Munitions Bunker](/card/23003) more than once when you are in hero form.

[Agent 13](/card/27046) will ready any of the *S.H.I.E.L.D.* aupport cards you need (like [Munitions Bunker](/card/23003) for example).

[Field Agent](/card/27044) means you can use [Agent 13](/card/27046) and [Dum Dum Dugan](/card/27047) more effectively. For example, if you have 2 [Field Agent](/card/27044)s, you can use them together with any other 3 *S.H.I.E.L.D.* cards to deal 6 damage with [Dum Dum Dugan](/card/27047) for no consequential damage. And you can do this multiple times. **MAD!**

And [Sky-Destroyer](/card/27055) will casually deal 2 damage (4 damage if you ready it with [Agent 13](/card/27046) every phase you play a *S.H.I.E.L.D.* card.

And all this is on top of what [War Machine](/card/23001a) deck can already do, and it can do a lot!

The deck is packed with a lot of damage, thwart and survivability. It's really fun and challenging to play it.

...

**If you prefer your deck to be a bit slimmer**, you can get rid of any of the following cards: [Crew Quarters](/card/20029), [Down Time](/card/05033), [Endurance](/card/05023), [Sense of Justice](/card/14030), [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065), [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047) and [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191). Removing all of them will trim down the deck to 42 cards.

I prefer playing those cards because of the following reasons:

- [Crew Quarters](/card/20029) - you will spend a lot of time in *Alter-Ego*.
- [Down Time](/card/05033) - you will find yourself in a position where you need to use your *Recovery*.
- [Endurance](/card/05023) - extra 3 *Hit Points* can be the difference between dead and alive [War Machine](/card/23001a), and it cost only one resource.
- [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) will give you this little bit of extra *Thwart* for when you need it, and we all know [War Machine](/card/23001a)'s biggest weakness is *Thwart*.
- [Sense of Justice](/card/14030) - you have only 2 *Thwart* events in this deck, but the cost to play [Targeted Strike](/card/23009) is 1, which means you will never need to spend another resource for it if you have [Sense of Justice](/card/14030) down.
- [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047) is at a cost of 0 and it will occasionally allow you to draw an extra card. Even if there is only one *Side Scheme* defeated during the whole game, the card has paid for itself.
- [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) provides you with a lot of benefits, the extra +1 hand size is the biggest one. The drawback is the extra encounter card you will receive every phase, and unfortunately, [War Machine](/card/23001a) doesn't have built-in mechanics to negate *Treachery* cards, but I think it's well worth the risk.

If you really want to get rid of some cards at least, [Endurance](/card/05023), [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) and [Sense of Justice](/card/14030) are the best candidates for it.

name: Spectrum, “Mega Draw Change Form” [Justice]
description_md: Play testing Spectrum, I found that she could have a “dead turn” due to not getting a change form card. She has great stats if she is in the correct form, but if not she is a ms marvel 1/1/1. Playing an aspect that could give card draw would maximize the chance every turn you have a change from card and thus could have great turns with her. This deck takes advantage of that.

name: Phoenix (Threat Moderator)
description_md:
Worked great in a campaign as the main threat moderator, played along with two other players using Aggression and Leadership etc. Had a lot of fun with this deck, may tweak it more as I continue the campaign and open to any suggestions/notes. 

Some fun moments:

Heroic Intuition is great to keep your thwart effective after you swap into unleashed. 

Swift retribution, followed by a basic thwarting followed by Turn the Tide was a fun combo for some good damage and still managing to remove a lot of threat.

White hot room, is a great way to recover with out using her actual recovery, switching back and forth often gives you a nice opportunity to use Lay Down the Law. 

Psychic Manipulation can be used in Alter ego or Hero mode.  

Power of justice helps keep the cost of Banshee and Marvel Girl down, followed up by mission training.

name: SCL 1303 -  Nebula Aggression vs Standard Ronan + Under Atta
description_md:
My official deck for Solo Champions League Season 13, Round 3:

* Round 3 - Ronan the Accuser + Under Attack + Power Stone [Starts with Hero] + Ship Command (12/24/22-01/14/23)
* Difficulty: Standard
* Hero: Drax, Gamora, Groot, Nebula, or Star-Lord
* Aspect: Aggression
* Campaign Elements:
+ 4 Units [GMW Marketplace]

I won in 10, 7 and 9 turns respectively, with clean boards and above starting health. I spent my 4 units on [Hyper Thrusters](/card/16164)

Notes:
* [Energy Spear](/card/22032) was included with [Bug](/card/16040) as the primary target, but Nebula's activations tend to go to thwarting, healing and attachments from Under Attack, so I was not able to use the Bug engine. I gave the Spear to Groot in the 7-turn game and he made good use of it. But it is one of the first things I would look at cutting
* I ended up recovering in AE multiple times per game and could have benefited from a little more healing help like [Crew Quarters](/card/20029)
* [Audacity](/card/21046) was included to help with dealing with the tough status cards that Ronan likes to collect, but it was relatively rare that it hit. With all of the other resource cards, cutting Audacity would reduce the chance of junk hands. 
* The MVPs were [Psylocke](/card/35013) letting me flip twice or protecting me from an Advance when in hero form and Wolverine for pushing so much piercing damage.
* [Target Acquired](/card/08024) was a really good call as a 2 of and it ended up getting used every game
* Leaving allies at 2HP instead of 1HP to protect from [Concussive Blast](/card/01154) ended up feeling like the right choice, even if it slowed things down. There were multiple times it prevented me taking a full Ronan to the face.

**Update Jan. 4**
* After further discussions on the SCL discord and trying him out in my Star-Lord deck, the Drax ally with Energy Spear feels like a much better choice than Wolverine

name: Phoenix and Friends
description_md:
This deck takes advantage of a few things. 
1. Phoenix can generate a wild resource once per phase when she has power counters, and she can do chunks of damage to the villain easily during both phases thanks to the extra resource availability.
2. Cyclops gives Phoenix 2 extra power counters while in play, and can be kept on the board for a long while with protective training.
3. Mutant protectors pairs very well with the enter play abilities of Professor X and Polaris, as well as Colossus' natural toughness.

Generally with this deck it is best to look to play your defense events as often as possible, as they are often better than Phoenix's hero events, drawing cards back with defensive energy, getting tough blockers into play to then stay, and chunking down the villain and minions with Powerful Punch and Psychic Misdirection. Play to get Team-Building Exercise, Avengers Mansion, and Cerebro online, controlling the board with your huge thwart stat and your allies' activations, particularly activations from Storm and Cyclops, who are best suited for Protective Training. Use your other allies for blocks when they are needed, play Rise From the Ashes at the end of your first or during your second deck pass, and line yourself up to go Unleashed right around the time you flip the villain to their final stage. White Hot Room helps a lot with this, even if you only use it on one or two flip-downs. Phoenix's events really only need to be played when absolutely necessary prior to going Unleashed, aside from Phoenix Firebird which should almost always be played for an extra counter or two, and don't bother with Phoenix Suit. Once you do go Unleashed, your deck will be somewhat thinned and you'll see your events more frequently, just when you need them. Continue to look for opportunities to play Powerful Punch, use your basic attack activations for three damage, and trust in your ability to rise from the ashes, using all of your allies' activations for attacking (or thwarting if absolutely necessary). Phoenix's kit is best when you play a control style until you are ready to go Unleashed, but with her Restrained thwart stat being large and her allies being quite good at thwarting as well, she doesn't reap as much benefit from justice as she can from protection, particularly protection cards that can deal solid chunks of damage, getting you through minions and the opening stage of the villain, allowing you to line up your timing of going Unleashed with relative ease as you can always spend two power counters in a round, meaning that playing it safe with your counters will never be able to block you from accessing the fullest power of the Phoenix Force when you decide you are ready.

name: Born to be Wild
description_md:
Nova is a hero I didn't play enough when he first came out. With the recent release of new wild resources for each of the aspects, it's time to revisit him.

Move over, [Energy](/card/01088), [Genius](/card/01089) and [Strength](/card/01090). A wild resource is even better than a double while playing Nova. Since his hero kit can dish out a steady amount of damage, it doesn't require adding that much more to get a winning deck. Card draw is much more crucial to Nova's game plan - and no one can argue that [One Way or Another](/card/22015) isn't a strong card.

This deck requires very little setup to get going. I like the hand smoothing of [Champions Mobile Bunker](/card/28020), but if aiming for a quick win (which this deck can offer against most villains) I might just chuck it as a resource. 

If playing solo [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) doesn't do much; another ally can probably take it's place. I kept the ally suits thematic, with Champions only. Any low cost chump blocker will work well in this deck.

name: Spider-Woman & the defenders
description_md:
In hopes that ffg do a defenders| king pin expantion box this year :)

To start i absolutely LOVE this deck...
Loads of stun, confuse and card draw
The allies do alot of the heavy lifting for damage output and also thwarting.
Spider-Woman fills in the gaps 

It's definitely the longer game with not a massive amount of attack power but it's a smooth and cozy ride into the end game

Chance encounter enables you to dig up whatever defender is needed from the deck or Discard pile 
Giving you a stress free run to chump block 

one way or another helps draw into the combos along side skilled investigator and clear the area plus captian marvel.

Using night nurse and med team keep allies on the battlefield for longer captian marvel is the main target for healing as to draw as much as possible.

A combo once set up is:
one way of the other to dig up a side sceme and draw 3 then captian marvel twarts draws a card, clear the area to finish it off and draw again then exhaust skilled investigator to draw yet again giving you a total of 6 cards in 1 turn

Pheromones, iron-fist and tackle to stun /confuse allows some breathing room to set all this up

Sidenote: 
Would be weak against villians with not many side schemes also minions that have massive attack and hit points could be a bit of a challenge but besides that the deck is alot of fun to pilot

name: Overwatch Duty
description_md:
Venom is just the best at overwatch duty. 

The power of basic cards like Nick Fury and Avenger's Mansion have always been good.. but expensive. Well, with Groot being one of the best allies (an auto-include imo if you're a guardian), let's just go full basic with low cost justice.

Basic cards bring us great allies like Nick Fury, Groot, Vivian (potentially game-breaking), and Rocket Raccoon. On top of that, it also brings us Avenger's Mansion more consistantly and Helicarrier more easily.

Justice brings us card draw in One Way or Another, and Skilled Investigator, and Overwatch can double our thwarting amounts when those sides schemes come out.

This is easily one of ,if not the best, decks that I've made. Though with Venom already being one of the best all-rounders, I guess that's not saying much.

name: Spider-Woman INFINITE DAMAGE & THWART
description_md:
This build only works in multiplayer.


The core of this build are 3 cards [Captain Marvel](/card/04032), [Game Time](/card/33022) and [Honorary X-Men](/card/33035). You would need someone to play [Honorary X-Men](/card/33035) on your Captain Marvel Ally. Once you get your Honorary X-Man equip your Training upgrades to Cpt Marvel.


The deck build concept is to thin your deck as much as possible by placing cards in play and putting as much draw as possible into your deck. Once all your cards are on the field and you are left with only events in your deck flip into alter-ego.
Then you will [Jessica Drew's Apartment](/card/04034), [Hall of Heroes](/card/06017), [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091), [Strength In Numbers](/card/03017) to draw your entire deck. 

Then you will infinitely recur [Game Time](/card/33022) while Captain Marvel Ally goes Ham on everything on the board.

Warning!
Villains with retaliate will break this build.


Final Notes 
This was just a deck I slapped together to try for fun. It worked in Standard1 Expert, but getting it online requires your teammates to help pick up the slack while you focus on setting up. 
The deck can be further optimized as some of the cards included were technically unnecessary, but I'll leave that to you.

name: Iron Man Energy to Repurpose
description_md: *“Iron Man. That’s kind of catchy. It’s got a nice ring to it. I mean it’s not technically accurate. The suit’s a gold titanium alloy, but it’s kind of provocative, the imagery anyway.” – Tony Stark: Iron Man* Iron Man *Protection*... this has always been a bit of a head-scratcher until now. The deck is much better and fun to play with the introduction of [Repurpose](/card/31016). Iron Man has always been outstanding in big damage output. His ability to ready with [Arc Reactor](/card/01035) and his 2 THW power, plus the [Mark V Helmet](/card/01037) made him decent enough for thwarting as well, but his issue always has been that he **MUST** spend the first few phases in *Alter-Ego*. This can lead to the Main Scheme getting out of control early on. A card like [Repurpose](/card/31016) can help you manage this, although it comes with the price of discarding one of your upgrades, which you desperately need, this can be the way to stay in the game. On top of that, adding a few recyclable *Protection Tech* upgrades like [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) and [Forcefield Generator](/card/31019) can go a long way into boosting any of the stats you need in a current situation throughout the game. Combine this with [Tony Stark](/card/01029b)'s awesome [Stark Tower](/card/01034), and recycling upgrades has never been easier. Plus, [Ingenuity](/card/29027) will help you play those upgrades in *Alter-Ego*, and [Crew Quarters](/card/20029) is a fun place to hang around at ( : ----- On another hand, at this deck [Nova](/card/05012) is like a support card. It will cost you one resource to activate him, but your deck is full of them, this will deal 2 damage to anyone who attacks you. [Jocasta](/card/26013) is there to simply keep hold or one copy of [Preemptive Strike](/card/05014) and you can always pay for it with [Nerves of Steel](/card/14017). Once this is done, she can thwart and be a chunk damage blocker. The rest of the cards which are not there for pure damage will generate the necessary resources you need to play all your events and will keep you safe. I must say that before [Repurpose](/card/31016) I was not a big fan of *Iron Man* Protection decks, but now I am really enjoying it, especially when I need this one or two extra damage or thwart, and I have *Repurpose* in my hand - ***Priceless***.

name: She-Hulk - Beginner's guide: Core Set Only
description_md: A while ago I started this series about Core Set decks, which I never actually got to finish (life, you know...). I read that there are tons of new Marvel Champions players this Holiday season so, I wanted to round up the 5 original heroes. If you are new to Marvel Champions, welcome! Marvel CDB is an awesome resource and I encourage you to dig for nice lists and tips. It can, however, be a challenge to keep up with all that's on the site. I already made lists for Black Panther, Captain Marvel and Spider Man using only core set cards: https://marvelcdb.com/decklist/view/21259/beginner-s-guide-core-set-only-1.0 https://marvelcdb.com/decklist/view/23032/captain-marvel-beginner-s-guide-core-set-only-1.0 https://marvelcdb.com/decklist/view/23222/spider-man-beginner-s-guide-core-set-only-1.0 Now, I tackle my fourth hero: She-Hulk. ________________________________ SOLO / MULTI? I made a multiplayer aggro list, but if you intend to try solo, I'll include a solo justice at the bottom. Why multi? Did you know that, according to the game developpers, Marvel Champions is designed and balanced for multiplayer (2 - 3 players)? That means solo play can be quite rough. Plus, if you've read a little about She-Hulk, you already know that she has bad press from a lot of players. Her playstyle presents a few challenges, and yes, some of her cards are considered sub-par and suffer from comparison with newer heroes and power creep. And so, the best way to enjoy She-Hulk with the limited options from just the core set, multiplayer seems like the best option. Just pair this list with the Captain Marvel or Black Panther one (links above), have BP take the [Tactical Genius](/card/01048) upgrade at setup, and have him or Marvel do the thwarting while, you punch, punch and punch! You can also use this deck to introduce a friend to MC. Who doesn't like to punch hard and destroy minions and the villain? ___________________________ Playing She-Hulk IMO, She-Hulk is a very interesting hero because she has strong incentives to flip every turn and use assets from her Alter-Ego as well as her Hero side. When you flip to Hero: - "do you even lift" gives you a free 2 dmg, unaffected by stuns or being exhausted. - With [Combat Training](/card/01057), you've got 4 ATK, and can attack a second time using [One-Two Punch](/card/01024). - Stun the villain using [Superhuman Strength](/card/01028) when you attack. - Dispatch the minions using [Relentless Assault](/card/01053), which lets you remove threaths with [Chase Them Down](/card/01052) and damage the villain with overkill. - Use [Focused Rage](/card/01027) to make up for the terrible 4 hand size. - use [Split Personality](/card/01025) to revert to AE and draw up to 6 cards. Take the opportunity to put costly assets/allies into play. - Everyone's She-Hulk favorite: [Gamma Slam](/card/01021) if the timing is right for incredible damage! When flip to AE: - you prevent one threath with "I object", - you thwart using [Superhuman Law Division](/card/01026), one of her top assets; - you can also thwart with [Legal Practice](/card/01023) (even though it is incredibly costly, one of the most criticized card in the entire game, it is better to use it than to lose to the threaths, right?). - use [Emergency](/card/01085) when the villain schemes to complement "I object" and prevent threaths. And so, by flipping every turn, you can use the best of both worlds, replenish your hand to 6 cards is a real blessing, as is the 2 dmg from "do you even lift?". And so, punch everything down! Another cool combo to notice, have [Hellcat](/card/01020) thwart, return her to your hand, play her right back and have her thwart again for 4 THW per turn! Some decks use cards from expansions to use this feature to the max. If you like this approach and want to push She-Hulk further into just punching, here are a few cards you may want too look into: - [Drop Kick](/card/10014), awesome if you can pay with 3 . [Martial Prowess](/card/10018) can help you get there. - [Limitless Stamina](/card/31023) to get even more readies, [Unshakable](/card/31024) to prevent stuns. - [Hand Cannon](/card/16046) can be pretty nice to get attack boosts and more overkill, or [Skilled Strike](/card/09037) for a 0-costed +2 atk. - [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019) if you can feed it . [Surprise Attack](/card/13014) too. ______________________ Solo option If you're truly into solo gaming, you can try to solo She-Hulk, but it may be more of a challenge than you think. Justice offers you more chance of pulling it off, so if you're into that (or stubborn like me!), try this for solo: [Nick Fury](/card/01084), [Mockingbird](/card/01083), [Daredevil](/card/01058), [Jessica Jones](/card/01059) [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091), [Helicarrier](/card/01092), 1 x [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) 1 x [Interrogation Room](/card/01063) [Genius](/card/01089), [Strength](/card/01090), [Energy](/card/01088), [The Power of Justice](/card/01062) x 2 3 x [For Justice!](/card/01060) 3 x [Surveillance Team](/card/01064) 3 x [Emergency](/card/01085) 3 x [Great Responsibility](/card/01061) (works only in hero form but can help against the villain getting [Advance](/card/01186)). If you like this solo justice approach, you may consider these cards as you expand your collection ; - [Agent Coulson](/card/08011) with [Counterintelligence](/card/08017) can make you returns to AE easier as you'll prevent more threaths. Coulson can also fetch you [Spycraft](/card/08018) to get rid of [Advance](/card/01186). - Same goes for "confuse" cards, such as [Sonic Rifle](/card/20015) / [Concussive Blow](/card/05031) (less effective than rifle though). - You could try the SHIELD archetype deck ([Nick Fury](/card/01084), [Agent Coulson](/card/08011),[Agent 13](/card/27046), [Quake](/card/08012), [Mockingbird](/card/01083), [Helicarrier](/card/01092), [Government Liaison](/card/27054), [Homeland Intervention](/card/27042), [Global Logistics](/card/27043)...). Most of it can be found in the Sinister Motives campaign box (campaigns are usually a good investment, full of new player cards and more scenarios). - [Sense of Justice](/card/14030) + [Clear the Area](/card/04049) and [Multitasking](/card/15013) for a lot of thwart! There it is! Next and last, Iron man (to come soon I hope) . Welcome to Marvel Champions and have fun!

name: SCL 1303 - Aggression Star-Lord vs Std Ronan
description_md:
For funsies deck for  Solo Champions League Season 13, Round 3:

* Round 3 - Ronan the Accuser + Under Attack + Power Stone [Starts with Hero] + Ship Command (12/24/22-01/14/23)
* Difficulty: Standard
* Hero: Drax, Gamora, Groot, Nebula, or Star-Lord
* Aspect: Aggression
* Campaign Elements:
+ 4 Units [GMW Marketplace]

Notes:
* You either chip away at Ronan with Drax and other Guardians with Energy spears or you have one of those Star Lord turns just falls into your lap, where you have a [Sliding Shot](/card/17005), a couple of copies of [Daring Escape](/card/17003) and the willingness to go for it.
* Star-Lord has a couple of things that line up nicely when playing Ronan.[Element Gun](/card/17007) has piercing so you want to get one out immediately, and it is needed later for the big [Sliding Shot](/card/17005) turn anyway.
* You can get a free encounter card from Ronan at any time when you detach the [Universal Weapon](/card/16109), so if you end up having things line up well for rushing, you can get extra Damage out of [Sliding Shot](/card/17005) thanks to the free encounter card Ronan was so generous to provide.

name: SCL 1303 - Aggression Drax vs Std Ronan
description_md:
For funsies deck for  Solo Champions League Season 13, Round 3:

* Round 3 - Ronan the Accuser + Under Attack + Power Stone [Starts with Hero] + Ship Command (12/24/22-01/14/23)
* Difficulty: Standard
* Hero: Drax, Gamora, Groot, Nebula, or Star-Lord
* Aspect: Aggression
* Campaign Elements:
+ 4 Units [GMW Marketplace]

Notes:
* Strategy: Take some hits to face to build up vengeance counters, while keeping your health up with a combination of [Mantis](/card/19002), [Endurance](/card/05023), [First Aid](/card/01086) and [Booster Boots](/card/16052). Blocking allies are there once your health is too scary low to carry on taking the Ronan attacks. At some point you will probably have to flip just to survive (feels bad).
* Managed to win 2 of 3 games with this, but the wins were not clean and all went to Stage 2 on the Main Scheme.
* Grabbed [Hyper Thrusters](/card/16164) with the 4 marketplace units
* I found that I usually needed to flip to Alter-Ego once per game, which always allowed the main scheme to advance to stage 2. One could try to bring in [Professor X](/card/32019) or [Psylocke](/card/35013) to avoid this, but I usually left the [Universal Weapon](/card/16109) out ([Sunfire](/card/35014) would only get rid of it if extremely convenient to do so). 
* I found I almost always had higher priorities than [Counterattack](/card/08030) and [Target Acquired](/card/08024). Also, the double resources were often used as single resources, so there are up to 5 cards in here that I would play around with replacing if I was trying to refine this deck.

name: Gamora Hones Her Anti-Ronan Technique
description_md:
This is for SCL S13 R3 - Guardians vs. Ronan.

On the attack side I went with [Honed Technique](/card/28017) to try for a few big swings against Ronan, with the idea to kill him quick once HT was in play. The old Dive Bomb and Melee options were off the table, due to Gamora not being aerial and not having any minions in this scenario. So I went with 3 copies each of [Uppercut](/card/01054) (3 resources for 8 attack) and [Piercing Strike](/card/04044) (2 resources for 5 attack plus piercing Ronan's tough).

Therefore the plan is - mulligan for Honed Technique, [Keen Instincts](/card/18009) and/or at least one ally to chump block.  Honestly the ally is particularly important since I had a few one-turn losses in practice games when I didn't prioritize allies. Lots of cheap allies are in here for chumpies. 

I kept the [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) since it was clutch in a practice game, but it never game into play in the real ones... Still the Wild Resource is nice...

I ended up with 2 out of 3 wins and a messy threat score.  But with Ronan... any battle you walk away from in a win!

name: Miles has status
description_md:
This deck has a major goal and a minor goal.

Both have to do with the key card - [Arachnobatics](/card/27031).

Major goal: status cards. 
This deck should FLOOD your enemy with stuns and confusions - while also splashing you with some toughs. The "protection" here isn't traditional defending. It's making sure your enemy can't attack (or scheme) in the first place.
And of course - adding status cards to the villain makes [Arachnobatics](/card/27031) an 8-damage card with a 1-cost. Pretty stellar.

(Of course, [Electrostatic Armor](/card/10031) and [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) are here to help deal damage to the villain when you DO want to defend - and [Never Back Down](/card/14014) can add a stun.)

Minor goal: replaying your best cards quickly.
This deck gives you multiple ways to put the good cards right back into your hand. The key is to build into the best turn: get both status cards onto your villain, then try to play [Arachnobatics](/card/27031) twice (at least) in the same turn for 16 damage.

name: Uncanny X-Men: SIN Cyclops
description_md:
What’s your favorite Aspect in Marvel Champions: Justice, Protection, Aggression or Strength In Numbers?

:-p

Cyclops is a pretty good fit for Strength In Numbers.  Not entirely natural at first (no burst economy) but there’s enough gradual incremental economic benefits that he quickly gets up to speed and can start to benefit from all the nice X-Men abilities from his allies.  Free Tough statuses (Polaris), free Minion removal (Magik), free recursion (Beast, Pixie, Phoenix) are yours to command.

What I initially felt was missing was a reliable source of villain-punishing damage but I think I’ve found that now by adding focus on Wolverine.  Danger Room Training and Inspired buff him up, Utopia let’s him double tap… Wolvie really is the best there is at what he does.

The other part I overlooked at first was how much Exploit Weakness adds to your damage output once you’ve got a stacked board if allies.

It’s a fun & solid deck which I’m going through the Mutants campaign with alongside Justice Storm.
