name: Valkillie
description_md:
In this game I have been blessed and cursed. My two favorite heroes from the comics have always been Dr. Strange and Valkyrie, for those who remember the old The Defenders comics.

Now, in this game Dr. Strange is both, fun to play and strong; while Valkyrie is both bland and weak. Nevertheless, I have been obstinate in making Valkyrie deck that is at least enjoyable to play and viable in true solo, which has lead to this deck.

It is an aggro deck that works best against villains with many minions, Klaw, Zola, Gru, Green Goblin... At least against such villains you will have fun drawing insane amount of cards and a high chance of victory.

I have tested the deck against Klaw, Zola and Green Goblin expert, works like a charm.

Happy gaming!

name: Spider-Man - Definitive - Expert
description_md:
This deck has been proving itself! It is Web-Warriors based and it uses the [Warrior of the Great Web](/card/30029) to boost [Spider-Man](/card/01001a) attack for a final blow.

This deck has beaten (so far) [Rhino](/card/01094)+ Sinister Syndicate, [Klaw](/card/01113) + Crossfire's Crew, [Crossbones](/card/04058) and [Taskmaster](/card/04093) - all of them in Expert.

There are 2 copies of [Warrior of the Great Web](/card/30029) and this assures that you draw it fast. You should not use your web-warriors to chump block, because you want them to leave play during your turn so you can get the +1 attack boost from [Warrior of the Great Web](/card/30029). This lasts only until the end of the phase, that is why you need to build up during the Hero phase.

It is very easy to manage threat, since you have [Clear the Area](/card/04049), [Crisis Averted](/card/15012) and [Lady Spider](/card/30012). You even have 2 copies of [Stealth Strike](/card/08013) to help ping damage around and remove threat at the same time.

If you go to alter-ego or draw an unwanted Advance while in hero form, use [Great Responsibility](/card/01061) to prevent the threat and run home to [Aunt May](/card/01006) so she can heal you.

Remember: "with great powers comes great responsibility". So make use of [Web-Shooter](/card/01008), [Deft Focus](/card/16024) and [Ingenuity](/card/29027) to keep these resources running.

This deck had only issue to deal with threat when I played against [Crossbones](/card/04058) since his main schema threshold are so low. But still I managed to win.

Have fun and leave a comment on improvements or changes, I would love to hear them =)

name: Mark I - Protection / Limited Card Pool
description_md:
With a limited card pool I tried to maximize protection for Ironman.

As a new player Standard Klaw got the better of me using a couple different core set decks. Squeaked 1 win by inches with Aggression Ironman -- But in first play test with this -- Klaw didn't get past the opening scheme. And it was the first time I had a blast playing protection.

If your just starting out in MC like me -Hopefully this inspires you to dabble in deck builds and gives you ideas with less cards.
 
Here's some tips for this deck with Ironman if you are new:

**Game Strategy:**
- Mulligan for suit items
- Prioritize building your suit fast and thwart as needed in the early game
- You can stay as hero most turns when your at 5+ hand draw.
- [Med Team](/card/01080)and [Jump Flip](/card/27014)help you stay there comfortably.
- [Jump Flip](/card/27014)combos well with [Indomitable](/card/01082)for bigger hits without ally's like [Luke Cage](/card/01076)
- Late game [Supersonic Punch](/card/01032), and [Repulsor Blast](/card/01031) will dish plenty of damage consistently. 
- [Return the Favor](/card/27015) splashes extra damage in a pinch -- more helpful in coop if you have enough thwart. Otherwise you could run [Bait and Switch](/card/15030).
- Always lookout for your mental cards to go aerial. [Rocket Boots](/card/01039) are very cyclable with [Pepper Potts](/card/01033) and [Stark Tower](/card/01034)


I'm looking forward to updating this when new cards arrive soon. Especially with Ms. Marvel.

name: Kitty Hits the Griddy 2: Electric Boogaloo
description_md:
Shadowcat can guarantee the triggers on **[Unflappable](/card/09020)** and **[Hard to Ignore](/card/16017)** using her **[Phased](/card/32031b)** constant effect, with minimal investment and often ending up with more cards in hand. With her defense well covered from her kit alone and extra resources from [Quick Shift](/card/32040) and [Unflappable](/card/09020) to prepare **tech**; we look to **[Repurpose](/card/31016)** to provide her with excellent burst thwart and damage. Using some neat cards like **[Jocasta](/card/26013)**, who recurs **[Quick Shift](/card/32040)**, and **[Forcefield Generator](/card/31019)**, which protects against small pings until going out in a blaze of glory, we can control and set up until it's time to burst down the villain. This deck was inspired by my previous deck, **Gwen Hits the Griddy**. Shadowcat and Ghost Spider have some notable differences. Ghost Spider readies easier for [Repurpose](/card/31016), while Shadowcat takes no damage for cheaper. Ghost Spider's damage potential is higher, but Shadowcat's better economy and thwart give her a flexible early game. Ghost Spider runs [True Grit](/card/18031) and Web-Warriors, while Shadowcat can afford and avoid the downsides of [Forcefield Generator](/card/31019).
## **How Does Shadowcat Work** ## Take a look at this video from community member **SC0E** who put out a great video explaining Shadowcat! This is a great primer on all the little quirks she presents. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2431JkwTEqY
## **Basic Form Technique** ## - [Phased](/card/32031b) is a **Forced Response**, making it mandatory to flip after an attack or defense and giving it timing priority over regular **Responses** - [Solid](/card/32031a) is merely a **Response** meaning the flip from [Solid](/card/32031a) to [Phased](/card/32031b) is optional after attacking or defending - **Attack** and **Defense** cards count as attacking and defending for [Phased](/card/32031b) and [Solid](/card/32031a), in addition to basic powers - Basic defending or playing a *(defense)* event only **begins** the defense. The defense shares an end window with the attack, so [Unflappable](/card/09020) and [Solid](/card/32031a)/[Phased](/card/32031b) do not trigger when Shadowcat plays her *(defense)*, but only **after** the defense ends, which is after step 4 of the enemy attack Basically, we want to end every hero phase in [Phased](/card/32031b), by flipping from [Solid](/card/32031a) with our last attack of the turn (remember we don't have to flip after every attack since [Solid](/card/32031a) is optional). Then we want to defend the villain attack, guaranteeing we take no damage.
## **Intermediate Form Stances** ## - When an enemy attack begins we can use [Quick Shift](/card/32040). As an **Interrupt**, it immediately draw 2 cards, before the attack resolves. As a *(defense)* card, this makes the attack considered defended without needing to exhaust - [Ready to Rumble](/card/32051) is essentially [Indomitable](/card/01082) for any aspect. If we exhausted to defend and thus trigger the **Forced Response** on [Phased](/card/32031b) to form change, we can trigger [Ready to Rumble](/card/32051) to ready. This is useful if we need to defend again or to start the hero phase unexhausted, guaranteeing an attack that can return Shadowcat to [Phased](/card/32031b) - [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) can trigger after we defend and use the **Forced Response** on [Phased](/card/32031b). Since it is an attack, it gives us the option to flip back to [Phased](/card/32031b). Useful if we need to defend again, or the first thing we want to do in the hero phase requires being phased such as *Selective Intangibility*, [Airwalk](/card/32039), [Phase Strike](/card/32038) - After the defense finishes, we will draw 1 card from [Unflappable](/card/09020), remove 1 threat from the main scheme with [Hard to Ignore](/card/16017), and deal 1 damage to the attacker with [Electrostatic Armor](/card/10031) This is the baseline, and it's already very good. Now let's turn it up a couple notches.
## **Advanced Form Mastery** ## Very important is that [Phased](/card/32031b) is a **Forced Response**, so the flip to [Solid](/card/32031a) occurs before all of our "after defends" **Response** cards such as [Unflappable](/card/09020), [Hard to Ignore](/card/16017), [Electrostatic Armor](/card/10031), [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022), and [Counter-Punch](/card/01077). The order the **Response** effects trigger is interchangeable. Rarely it matters, but remember that these can be triggered in the order of your choosing for when it does. More on this later. We could not play a [Quick Shift](/card/32040) drawn off of [Unflappable](/card/09020) here, since [Quick Shift](/card/32040)'s **Interrupt** timing is at the start of the attack; but we could play [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) drawn off [Unflappable](/card/09020), triggering a form change). - If we start in [Phased](/card/32031b), defend to flip to [Solid](/card/32031a), then [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) to flip back to [Phased](/card/32031b), our [Hard to Ignore](/card/16017) trigger will benefit from our ability to ignore **crisis**, since we are still in the same response window of "after you defended and took no damage". This would not work if Shadowcat ended in [Solid](/card/32031a), and is one example for the order of the triggers mattering - If we draw a second [Quick Shift](/card/32040) off the first, it is immediately playable, allowing us to draw 4 cards. [Quick Shift](/card/32040) can also draw into [Counter-Punch](/card/01077), which will be relevant later - In multiplayer, [Quick Shift](/card/32040) can make Shadowcat the new target of an attack since it is playable on an attack made against any player and *(defense)* makes her the defender. For example, in 2-player, Shadowcat basic defends the first attack from [Phased](/card/32031b), [Unflappable](/card/09020) draws [Counter-Punch](/card/01077), [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) puts [Shadowcat](/card/32030a) back in [Phased](/card/32031b), [Quick Shift](/card/32040) pulls the second attack, fully resolving in [Phased](/card/32031b) amounting to two attacks with no damage taken. [Shadow and Steel](/card/32050) also draws attacks against any player and works best from [Solid](/card/32031a), saving a [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022) or [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) and being paid for with [Solid](/card/32031a)'s free resource
Benefits so far: - Have mitigated step 1 villain phase threat with [Hard to Ignore](/card/16017) - Have mitigated step 2 of the villain phase by taking no damage from 1-2 villain attacks with [Phased](/card/32031b) - Have an effective 6 card hand with [Unflappable](/card/09020), and sometimes 7-8 card hand with 1-2 [Quick Shift](/card/32040) - Have potentially dealt villain/minion damage with [Counter-Punch](/card/01077), [Electrostatic Armor](/card/10031), or [Shadow and Steel](/card/32050) Since we have effectively turned off the villain for most of the villain phase with little effort, we really only need to answer encounter cards and beat the villain. My answer is [Repurpose](/card/31016). Increasing ATK takes care of minions and the villain, increasing THW takes care of side schemes, and the ready is good security against exhaustion/status and makes sure we can always get to [Phased](/card/32031b).
## **Tech Picks** ## Similar to my previous deck, **Gwen Hits the Griddy**, rather than double down on our defensive efforts, we will be looking for ways to turn our defense into offense. This is primarily for 1-2 player counts, where being well-rounded is better than being laser-focused. - **[Repurpose](/card/31016)** is a great way to supplement the offense of heroes with good access to readies - **[Electrostatic Armor](/card/10031)** is our main tech choice. It already flows well with our 1-2 defenses per round and is cheap. We are running two because this will be our primary [Repurpose](/card/31016) target- - **[Plasma Pistol](/card/20022)** makes the cut over [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) in our 2-cost spot. Shadowcat takes damage so irregularly, that getting the pings from [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) is inconsistent. [Plasma Pistol](/card/20022) is useful to tee up minions to the right health or ping toughs to let our large attacks thru - **[Forcefield Generator](/card/31019)** is a great one-of. Because of how little damage we take, it can stick around for awhile without discarding itself from its **Forced Interrupt**. Being max 1 and having good longevity means we really only want one copy, but it can stick around for a mega turn! - With [Repurpose](/card/31016), [Shadowcat Surprise](/card/32037), [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022), and [Professor X](/card/32019), we have 10 readies in deck to make use of these boosted stats. **[Ready to Rumble](/card/21022)** is showing that it is more flexible than [Indomitable](/card/01082) here, since we can trigger it in the hero phase after attacking and triggering a form change). The sequence would be [Repurpose](/card/31016)->attack->form change->ready to rumble->attack. At any point we are in [Solid](/card/32031a), we can play [Shadowcat Surprise](/card/32037) using [Solid](/card/32031a)'s resource and [Deft Focus](/card/16024) to deal 3 damage and attack again! - Remember when we said we would come back to drawing into **[Counter-Punch](/card/01077)** off of [Quick Shift](/card/32040)/[Unflappable](/card/09020)? When we [Repurpose](/card/31016) for attack in the hero phase, and then defend in the villain phase, we can trigger [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) to deal our boosted ATK value! This works because [Repurpose](/card/31016) boosts last until the *end of the round*, and as established earlier, the response window stays open throughout all of our "after defends" **Response** effects. This boosted [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) can be played off of any of the numerous defenses Shadowcat will make or as a card drawn by [Quick Shift](/card/32040)/[Unflappable](/card/09020). I've played some 7 ATK [Counter-Punch](/card/01077)s with this deck, but presumably it can get as high as 9! - Thwarting sequencing is a little more restricted, since we still need to attack at least once to get back to [Phased](/card/32031b). [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022) is tougher to pull off since a basic THW won't trigger a form change. But when Shadowcat does boost, ignoring **crisis** while [Phased](/card/32031b) can be beneficial to maximize value with fewer readies - **[Professor X](/card/32019)** is useful as a confuse+3 THW that isn't tied to stopping an attack like [Phased and Confused](/card/32036) is. The 3 THW means we can more often use [Repurpose](/card/31016) to boost attack, and his built in ready effect can let us swing again. We aren't running [Utopia](/card/33020) because triggering the ready effect is less reliable as [Shadowcat](/card/32030a) doesn't need allies, much like [Ghost-Spider](/card/27001a)
## **Superpowers** ## - **[Deft Focus](/card/16024)** hits [Shadowcat Surprise](/card/32037), [Phase Strike](/card/32038), [Airwalk](/card/32039), [Acute Control](/card/32034), and [Intangible Interference](/card/32035) - **[Shadowcat Surprise](/card/32037)** is our best card after [Quick Shift](/card/32040), at base 3 damage, 2 thwart, and a flip to [Phased](/card/32031b); but the numbers only go up with [Repurpose](/card/31016). [Solid](/card/32031a)+[Deft Focus](/card/16024) combine for a lot of free [Shadowcat Surprise](/card/32037)s - Note that [Solid](/card/32031a) with **[Phase Strike](/card/32038)** is less good, since [Phase Strike](/card/32038) resolves before [Solid](/card/32031a)'s **Response** can flip her to [Phased](/card/32031b), meaning she won't be able to discard an attachment. [Deft Focus](/card/16024) takes the place of [Solid](/card/32031a) here - **[Airwalk](/card/32039)** is amazing when paid for free from [Phased](/card/32031b), but don't overlook the option to play it for a base 2 threat removal as well - **[Intangible Interference](/card/32035)** can be great when we have a boosted thwart stat from [Repurpose](/card/31016) or can play a full strength [Airwalk](/card/32039). It gives a bonus 2 threat removal from a **crisis** side scheme at the cost of an exhaust, useful for things like [Hydra Patrol](/card/04154) or [Abduction Protocols](/card/32100). This must be done from [Phased](/card/32031b) - **[Acute Control](/card/32034)** is a bit more situational. Ignoring **guard** requires an attack from [Phased](/card/32031b) and thus a forced flip to [Solid](/card/32031a). While it can be useful against [Goblin Thrall](/card/02024)s, [M-Type Sentinel](/card/32146)s, and [Master Mold II](/card/32110), Shadowcat will still need a second attack to get back to [Phased](/card/32031b). Both of the upgrades are great [Caught Off Guard](/card/01188) fodder. Thinning the deck, perfect when there's an extra Deft Focus lying around
## **Notables** ## - **[Jocasta](/card/26013)** probably deserves her own section. She gets us a 3rd use of our best card, [Quick Shift](/card/32040), turning her into 2 ER for 4 THW and a block, or 2 ER for 2 THW and 2 blocks. Insane value. Getting 3-4 free blocks per deck cycle allows us to save our exhausts for big [Repurpose](/card/31016) turns - **[The X-Jet](/card/32020)** is a good economy card for the things [Deft Focus](/card/16024) can't touch, like the tech cards and allies. **[Honorary X-Men](/card/33035)** is here to give [Kitty Pride](/card/32030b) the **X-Men** trait so she can benefit from the in alter-ego. Useful to clear a few cards that give us a hard time like [Frozen](/card/21158) and [Seduced](/card/21179). The +1 hit point is situationally useful, against Ebony Maw’s spells for instance - **[Phased and Confused](/card/32036)** can sometimes be a hindrance since we can't trigger [Unflappable](/card/09020) if the villain doesn't attack. Turning off a villain attack and then drawing into [Quick Shift](/card/32040) feels really bad. It’s expensive and doesn’t working with [Deft Focus](/card/16024) or [Solid](/card/32031a). The confuse is useful, but against non-steady villains, [Professor X](/card/32019) is a better confuse. [Phased and Confused](/card/32036) can be good in circumstances where Shadowcat is stuck in [Solid](/card/32031a) or if she can hit [Unflappable](/card/09020) by defending a minion instead. It can buy time early game, before our [Unflappable](/card/09020) engine is set up. Just be careful when playing it that it doesn't shut down the engine entirely! - **[Kitty's Room](/card/32033)** is amazing burst heal. With two uses and a REC, mitigated by our copious readies, she can heal 7 damage quickly. Shadowcat *can* take no damage over the course of the game, but using her health as a resource can generate a lot of tempo in certain situations. Having the option to heal quickly comes in handy. When combined with *Phase Control*, she can choose the healing or draw depending on what's useful or what is in hand. If we have [Phase Strike](/card/32038) and the villain has an attachment, rolling into [Phased](/card/32031b) is prudent. If we just REC and have [Shadowcat Surprise](/card/32037), roll up to [Solid](/card/32031a) to pay for it and ready. If we have no way to attack, roll up to [Phased](/card/32031b) to prepare for the villain phase - In multiplayer with my Colossus deck, I replace x1 [Plasma Pistol](/card/20022) with x1 **[Shadow and Steel](/card/32021)**. It can draw attacks from other players, trigger [Unflappable](/card/09020), and deal some damage to the villain or hopefully clear a minion. This helps preserve Colossus' toughs ## **Should We Only Defend From Phased?** ## The benefits of defending from [Phased](/card/32031b) are clear: 1. Take no damage 2. Draw 2 cards from [Quick Shift](/card/32040) 3. Trigger [Unflappable](/card/09020) and [Hard to Ignore](/card/16017) If Shadowcat cannot meet these criteria, then she should not defend. She typically only wants to flip to [Phased](/card/32031b) off of [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) or after spending the [Solid](/card/32031a) in the hero phase; rather than flipping to [Phased](/card/32031b) from a defense trigger. Having reliable access to starting in [Phased](/card/32031b) and using [Quick Shift](/card/32040) three times per deck cycle (with help from [Jocasta](/card/26013)), should keep us covered; but what should Shadowcat do when attacked while in [Solid](/card/32031a), such as after a first defense from [Phased](/card/32031b) or the rare occasion of starting a villain phase in [Solid](/card/32031a)? My baseline advice is don't defend in [Solid](/card/32031a), unless able to meet 1., 2., or 3. above. Blocking some damage is not worth the expenditure in exhausts or resources. There are a handful allies that can stick around as emergency chumps, but don’t be afraid to tank a full attack. [Kitty's Room](/card/32033) can burst heal [Kitty Pride](/card/32030b), so taking damage is a minor inconvenience. However, if we can guarantee a combination of the above points, defending from [Solid](/card/32031a) becomes a better value proposition. - [Quick Shift](/card/32040) can get us 1. and 3. for instance, by flipping to [Phased](/card/32031b) and thus taking no damage. Though losing the draw 2 is a shame. Definitely evaluate if it is worth it to burn a [Quick Shift](/card/32040) this way before playing it, as holding it for next turn to defend and draw 2 is also viable - Defending a minion attack or having [Forcefield Generator](/card/31019) active can guarantee 1. And 3, while also saving some energy counters - Multiplayer provides more reason to defend from [Solid](/card/32031a). [Shadow and Steel](/card/32021) can use the [Solid](/card/32031a) resource, hitting 1. and 3. We can use [Counter-Punch](/card/01077) after our first defense from [Phased](/card/32031b) to flip back and take a second attack from [Phased](/card/32031b). Lastly, we can exhaust to defend in [Solid](/card/32031a) as long as we have an in-hand [Quick Shift](/card/32040) for the second defense from [Phased](/card/32031b)

name: Quicksilver vs. The Side Schemes
description_md:
[**EDIT:** Apparently I can't change a deck after publishing it, but Martinex should be replaced by [Cosmo](/card/17020).]

This deck was built off a prompt to make a Quicksilver Justice deck using [Problem Solvers](/card/25033). The idea is to use [Chance Encounter](/card/26034) to tutor [Eros](/card/22011) and keep him out until you can play [Problem Solvers](/card/25033), hopefully after you've played [Maximum Velocity](/card/14005) and (on a prior turn) [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) and [Hyper Perception](/card/14010), potentially removing 7 threat from each scheme! [Cosmo](/card/17020) is a backup for Problem Solvers in case you can't find Eros at the right time.

With a hand size of 5, you have 3 resources to play those two cards (total cost 6). With [Friction Resistance](/card/14009), [Deft Focus](/card/16024), and [Sense of Justice](/card/14030) this is an affordable turn for our speedy hero even if he hasn't gotten a chance to play [Quincarrier](/card/08023) yet.

For the rest of the game, this is a pretty normal thwarting deck. [Clear the Area](/card/04049) and [Multitasking](/card/15013) for side schemes, [Followed](/card/03032) to leverage those events into damage, [Justice Served](/card/22014) to give you extra readies after they do their job, and a handful of amenities from our yellow library.

While I designed this deck with Red Skull in mind, an alternative and more general approach here would be to swap in [One Way or Another](/card/30017), likely in place of [Followed](/card/03032), to help bring side schemes out in scenarios that don't have very many of them, giving you greater opportunity to draw into your combos.

name: Phoenix and the Danger Room + Cerebro + Forge
description_md: A slight modification to a popular Phoenix justice deck centered around the X-Men supports.  The goal is to flip to alter ego and play buffed-up justice allies to manage thwart, letting Phoenix go into unleashed without worrying about schemes. This version includes Forge to help get Cerebro and Danger Room out earlier and eliminates the Psionic events because I frequently found there wasn't enough threat on the board to justify a 3 resource event that did no damage.  With White Hot Room and X-Mansion, she can heal for 6 with each flip to alter ego, so I thought the endurance was a bit wasted on a 9 health hero.

name: Ghost - 01
description_md:
The main idea is to use [Fluid Motion](/card/28016) [Follow Through](/card/16045) and [Hand Cannon](/card/16046) to skewer the villain through minions using Gwen’s attack event synergy.


First attempt here.  I’d really like to get the number of cards down to target attack events but support and upgrade cards will do that naturally.  Time will tell which cards carry the weight here and I’ll narrow that down after a few plays.

name: Venom Reborn
description_md:
*"Trapped with no way out. The rage feeds my symbiote. The rage makes it strong. It chose me -- knows I need it -- knows my thoughts. Distorts perceptions. There is no controlling it. Gives me what I need to plow these bastards over. Pay them back for the way they've treated me. They have no idea the beast they've awoken... they will." - Flash Thompson: Venom Vol 2 #12"*

A *Justice* Venom deck is a fun one. Having two ways to *confuse* an enemy is just priceless. Taking full advantage of *Venom* and *Flash Thompson* abilities. Let's break it down.

**Allies**
- [Wraith](/card/22012) is used to take care of any nasty effects during the *Villain* phase. He is like a support card with 3 counters on it.
- [Drax](/card/18019) provides a lot of punch to the villain only, this is because Drax doesn't like small targets in general ;)
- [Gamora](/card/19020) gives access to the events, it's like an extra card draw.
- [Martinex](/card/21065) is cheap to play so easy to get on the board.
- [Jack Flag](/card/20011) is a thwarting power. With [Mission Training](/card/34016) attached, he can do a lot of thwarting and a lot of damage over time.

**Events**
- The only additional event to the core deck is ["Think Fast!"](/card/19031). It is essential as it will allow more frequent use of the *Alter-Ego* use of *Recovery* and [Project Rebirth 2.0](/card/20007).

**Supports**
- As we all know, *Justice* is all about controlling the *Threat*. Therefore, 3 copies of [Beat Cop](/card/10029). Expensive, but once on the board, the threat will never be a problem again.
- [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091) and [Knowhere](/card/17022) are cards drawing power.
- [Crew Quarters](/card/20029) is essential as going to *Alter-Ego* is necessity.
- [Helicarrier](/card/01092) is just awesome for what it does, plus it looks cool.
- [CITT](/card/17021) is situational, and more often than not, will not be played, but it has saved me numerous times in desperate moments when I needed this tiny bit of extra damage or extra thwart.

**Upgrades**
- [Mission Training](/card/34016) to be swapped with [Interrogation Room](/card/01063).
- [Sense of Justice](/card/14030) is perfect for [Behind Enemy Lines](/card/20002) as it generated the resource needed to confuse the enemy,
- [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047) is paying for itself in any game.
- [Down Time](/card/05033), [Endurance](/card/05023) and [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) will boost the *recovery* and *health point* plus *Symbiote Suit* will boost the hand size and every other basic stat *(the extra encounter card is a small price to pay)*.

The deck is very versatile and can control the threat while outputting the necessary damage.

--**Side note**--

After set-up, [Locked and Loaded](/card/20004) becomes a bit of a dead weight, but I simply cannot justify including [Sonic Rifle](/card/20015) and [Side Holster](/card/20021) in the deck. If **you** want to include them, you can swap one copy of ["Think Fast!"](/card/19031) and [Mission Training](/card/34016) for them.

**UPDATE** 
- Change [Mission Training](/card/34016) with [Interrogation Room](/card/01063).

name: Black Panther Leader of The Pack
description_md:
Black Panther, Leader of Wakanda has a new role; Leader of the Avengers. 

This deck is all about having as many allies on the board as possible using [Avengers Tower](/card/03024) (plus Squirrel Girl does not count) , keeping them alive for as long as possible with [Reinforced Suit](/card/12018) and [United We Stand](/card/14031), using them as many times as possible each turn using [Get Ready](/card/01069) and [Sky Cycle](/card/04015) and then getting them back as soon as possible with [Make the Call](/card/01071) and then [Leadership Training](/card/25034) can return Make The Call etc return to your hand. 

The Allies are interchangeable depending on taste and situation. 

The two [The Power of Leadership](/card/01072) are optional.

name: She-Hulk R&R
description_md:
Jen doesn't let the stress of being a She-Hulk and lawyer get her down. Why? Because she also knows how to chill out and take some much needed R&R.

EDITS***
Remove: 1xAssess the Situation. 1xRecuperation. 1xCaptain America

Add: 2x [R&D Facility](/card/29020) Should have been a no brainer. Jenni’s easily swinging for 8 or 12 with 1 boosted stat and drawing into one of her 6 readying cards. in a bind, she can manage scheme this way also.

1x [Kaluu](/card/21014) to help her find events and still have resources to play them.

This deck was created for the Deck Factory Discord Challenge found here>>>https://discord.gg/cCG6YCFN . If you are looking for some more Champions community or challenges, come on down. This challenge - use the oft overlooked [Recuperation](/card/15031).

It's supposed to be Jen's vacay with Matt Murdock, but Smart-Hulk is out of town and [Nick Fury](/card/01084) is in need of some help. He's sent [Maria Hill](/card/01067) to recruit She-Hulk for some support. Reluctantly, she agrees...and lets [Daredevil](/card/31014) stay on the beach (unless you are playing two handed or multiplayer, in which case i'd encourage you to bring him along*).

Obviously, she has got it all under control....but this was supposed to be time for her to rest up. What happens if she's running on empty and that health starts getting low? Obviously, she'll take advantage of [Gamma Slam](/card/01021) but this was supposed to be vacation. Answer....flip down to get some Rest & [Recuperation](/card/15031).

What better way to get from 1HP to 15HP than setting up with [Down Time](/card/05033), making a basic recovery for 7 and then doing it all over again a second time. There is already so much to do as Jennifer Walters like removing threat from behind a desk at the [Superhuman Law Division](/card/01026), or resetting her hand and multiple threats with her mad [Legal Practice](/card/01023) skills.

Striking balance with a little 'me' time can also be great for [Clarity of Purpose](/card/31029) and probably accounts for her steady [Unshakable](/card/31024) nature. Jen is able to build her case, sacrificing a little health in a controlled manner, whilst also getting ready to outsource some of the heavy lifting to high ticket colleagues like [Captain America](/card/21011), or opening a second office in the [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091).

Cool, calm, and in control....with the occasional bout of [Split Personality](/card/01025) or going into a [Focused Rage](/card/01027). Understandable, no-one likes cutting their PTO short.


*This may make little sense if you haven't seen the mini series.

name: Captain Marvel Pumps and Burns
description_md:
This is a multideck combo deck that was built to work in pairing with the She-Hulk Aggression as a part of the MCM New Player's Guide month! A link to the pairing deck is here:
https://marvelcdb.com/decklist/view/25757/she-hulk-smashes-and-smashes-and-smashes-and-smashes-1.0

What happens when we open the cardpool up to really modify our last multiplayer builds? 

We can do two things:
 - Make our own combo more consistent with additional cheap allies and ways to draw to our combo pieces faster (see [White Tiger](/card/21013) and [Assess the Situation](/card/12033)).
 - Create fun multideck combos (using [R&D Facility](/card/29020) to pump She-Hulk and [Lead from the Front](/card/01070) to pump  your own board or the other players!

Here the goal is to pump She-Hulk's board and use our allies to keep the teams alive via chumping and thwarting. Carol take a back set until [She-Hulk](/card/01019a) is set-up and then they set up an epic 2-deck [One-Two Punch](/card/01024)! Also don't discount the all female A-force ally line-up!

Mulligan tips:
 -  Dig deep for an [R&D Facility](/card/29020) or 2+ allies. You will be holding down the fort while [She-Hulk](/card/01019a) sets up. Once she is up and running use [Agent 13](/card/27046) with [R&D Facility](/card/29020) to really give She-Hulk a boost.

name: She-Hulk Smashes and Smashes and Smashes and Smashes
description_md:
This is a multideck combo deck that was built to work in pairing with the Captain Marvel Leadership as a part of the MCM New Player's Guide month! A link to the pairing deck is here:
https://marvelcdb.com/decklist/view/25756/captain-marvel-pumps-and-burns-1.0

What happens when we open the cardpool up to really modify our last multiplayer builds? 

We can do two things:
 - Make our own combo more consistent (additional readies in [Earth's Mightiest Heroes](/card/04022) and [Limitless Stamina](/card/31023) and additional stat pumps in [Adrenaline Rush](/card/14022)).
 - Create fun multideck combos (passing [Combat Training](/card/01057) or [Boot Camp](/card/13016) to [Carol Danvers](/card/01010b))

Here the goal is to pump She-Hulk's stats and make use of the 9 event readies in the deck. Watch for stat pumps from [Carol Danvers](/card/01010b) [Lead from the Front](/card/01070) and [R&D Facility](/card/29020) and don't forget your own [Combat Training](/card/01057) and [Adrenaline Rush](/card/14022). Also don't discount the all female A-force (plus Bruce) ally line-up!

It is not uncommon to end up with an ATK of 5+ and 2-3 readies in hand by the end of the game.

Mulligan tips:
 -  Dig deep for a Combat Training or a few allies to set-up [Earth's Mightiest Heroes](/card/04022) don't focus on the ready cards to begin with but your set-up. If possible never pass up on an [Adrenaline Rush](/card/14022) as they can really pay off!

name: Worldmind Over Matter aka Draw and Roll
description_md:
Nova is well known as a minion monster at this point in the game, but an often overlooked benefit of [Unleash Nova Force](/card/28006) is that you get the same effect when all threat is removed from a scheme. So…let’s take his controlling of board states to 11!

Draw, draw, draw. 

[Clear the Area](/card/04049) while Unleashing the Nova Force gets you 2 cards if you remove all the scheme + 1 from [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047) if it was a defeated Side Scheme.

 [Turn the Tide](/card/15015) after clearing threat from a scheme will also often net 2 if you can defeat a minion with TtT. Even if you can’t you get the ready to possibly take them out or keep Thwarting. [One Way or Another](/card/22015) needs little explanation but it gives you both card draw and targets to clear. 

And of course you have the likes of Fury and [Moon Girl](/card/28018) to each frequently give you 3 more cards.

On turns with less explosions [Justice Served](/card/22014) can help you ready for more resources from the Helmet.

The deck as posted is geared solo, but is easily scalable into higher play counts, starting with swapping out [Pivotal Moment](/card/18029) with [Agile Flight](/card/17029) and possibly swapping OWOA with more [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047) to help your team. I would recommend lower player counts for this though simply for the fact your turn goes a lot longer as you can do so much!

For those who don’t want to include ["Go for Champions!"](/card/29025) as it is incredibly busted I’d recommend another [Justice Served](/card/22014) or [Adrenaline Rush](/card/14022) for more damage when you Unleash. A third [Turn the Tide](/card/15015) isn’t a bad idea either. 

Thanks for checking this out!

name: Venom x Wolverine
description_md:
*"I've taken beatings in my life. Had body and mind put to the test. Football. Dad. Boot camp. Mosul. Both legs amputated above the knee. An entire lifetime of getting my ass kicked to the ground can't begin to measure up to these past twelve hours." - Flash Thompson: Venom Vol 2 #9"*

Venom is an interesting hero deck to play. The combination of Venom/Flash Thompson *Space Knight* is an interesting choice from the Marvel Champions developers. This is not the Venom everyone knows from the Spider-Man movies, but a different, more mature and developed Venom. I just LOVE IT!

The core deck is very balanced and comes with everything you would need from a deck. A little bit of *thwart*, a bit of *damage*, a bit of *defense* and some boosts from the upgrades. As the core deck is covering all the basics, I have decided I do not need to include anymore events in the deck, as Venom got this covered. All cards included are here to support Venom doing what he does best, and this is everything.

---

**The allies**

All allies with the exception of [Wolverine](/card/32041) are *Guardians*, where *Wolverine* is an [Honorary Guardian](/card/22035).

[Drax](/card/18019) has great damage output. [Gamora](/card/19020) will get an event when she attacks or thwarts, [Groot](/card/16047) can be kept on the board to defend against minions, and thanks to his effect, he will most often than not get healed to full. [Martinex](/card/21065) is cheap and efficient to play.

[Wolverine](/card/32041) is like a permanent support card. Once he is on the board, thanks to [Locked and Loaded](/card/20004) upgrades for him are easy to be obtained and he can be geared up with extra 3 attack points (5 including [Boot Camp](/card/13016)) and extra 1 hit points. *Wolverine*'s ability to heal means that every other turn he can attack for 7 with *Ranged* and *Piercing* and of course if times are truly desperate, he can be a chunk damage blocker, but let's try to avoid using him for this...

---

All **Events** are from the core set and after set-up, it is easy to cycle through them and play 2-3-4 events each round.

**Support and Upgrades**

- [Boot Camp](/card/13016) is great as the deck wants to cycle through your allies (with the exception of [Wolverine](/card/32041)).
- [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091), [Hall of Heroes](/card/06017) and [Knowhere](/card/17022) will allot the draw of extra cards.
- [CITT](/card/17021) will turn any brick hand into a playable hand, and in combination with the two [Venom's Pistol](/card/20010) and [Combat Training](/card/01057) this can mean 5 extra damage this turn, or 3 extra thwarts.
- [Helicarrier](/card/01092), [Martial Prowess](/card/10018) and Venom's *Symbiotic Bond* are a great combination to pay for event cards and allies.
- [Energy Spear](/card/22032), [Honorary Guardian](/card/22035) and [Sidearm](/card/23035) are to be attached to [Wolverine](/card/32041).
- [Side Holster](/card/20021) will allow the play of 4th *Restricted* weapon - [Hand Cannon](/card/16046). 
- As spending time as *Flash Thompson* is very beneficial, and very useful to recover some *HP*, [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022) will allow to recover twice if necessary and then flip to *Hero* form and be ready to, well, rumble.
- [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) is simply a **MUST** in Venom's deck because, c'mon... it's Venom...



--**Side Note**--
Once the deck has trimmed down to allies, events and resources, thanks to [Locked and Loaded](/card/20004), it will be easy to pull out [Hand Cannon](/card/16046) after all counters are used.

name: Hulkverine
description_md: Hulk + Wolverine, Beat the villain and his minions with Hulk and his _boosted_ friend Wolverine! __Considrations__ - This deck has been created for multiplayer, focused in dealing basic attack + heavy attack event per turn with Hulk and empowering Wolverine to make him a 5 ATK beast with 6 HP _ranged_ and _piercing_! - For triggering additional effects that require a resource, the whole deck contains the desired printed resource but 3: [Banner's Laboratory](/card/10008) (mandatory), [Quincarrier](/card/08023) and [Ingenuity](/card/29027)... which are resource generators! - No other double resources as [Genius](/card/01089) and [Energy](/card/01088) added for fulfilling the previous topic. - Cost-4 cards avoided, except from [Wolverine](/card/32041). - As Wolverine is the only ally, two copies of [Attack Training](/card/32043) and [Sidearm](/card/23035) are added. In case you have both in play, you can use them as a precius resource :-) __Pros__ - Tons of damage :-) - Duplicated upgrades as [Combat Training](/card/01057), [Martial Prowess](/card/10018) can boost other Heroes. __Cons__ - Not a thematic deck (x-men ally, hulk with weapon...). - Obviusly not designed for solo play. - Initial turns might be hard, with difficult choices to take. I hope you like it!

name: Pesky Raccoon Baffles and Befuddles
description_md:
<hr>

Remember when you opened Cyclops' hero pack and proceeded to completely ignore [Befuddle](/card/33033)? Sick of it just sitting around, taking up valuable storage space?

Enter this deck, my attempt of taking an unloved card and giving it its best home possible. There are a few other contenders for the best user of [Befuddle](/card/33033), Phoenix in particular, but at the end of the day Rocket is rewarded for defeating minions and that's what Befuddle is all about!

Rocket also gets access to ["Think Fast!"](/card/19031), a great card for the theme of the deck with Rocket bewildering and confusing his enemies. You might be thinking that, if this deck is meant to be thematic, then why is Rocket (a Guardian) running around with [Professor X](/card/32019) and [Nick Fury](/card/01084)? Well! If you're confused about that, then I'm afraid to say you've already been befuddled by the pesky raccoon! ;D

At the time of posting, I have handily defeated both Expert Drang and Expert Magneto with this deck.

<hr>
**If you like this deck, feel free to give it a ❤ ! Thank you!**
<hr>

(_Note: This deck, as posted, is ideal for 1-2 players. If you want to play this in 3-4 player, keep in mind that this deck is an all-rounder and will not be able to reliably handle all the threat for so many players. Think of it as taking the Leadership role of providing whatever is necessary. More details can be found in the **Strategy** section, and ways to adapt the deck for 3-4 player threat removal can be found in **Alternative Cards**._)

<hr>
#### **Key Cards & Abilities:**
<hr>

- [Befuddle](/card/33033) - This card is the center point of the deck, from which all other choices have been made. Slap it on a minion, and now you're dealing damage to it equal to your THW when you attack. So how do we make this work?

- "Murdered You!" - This is Rocket's hero-form ability. Deal excess damage to a minion, draw a card. It's extremely potent card draw that only gets better based on the quantity of minions in a scenario. [Befuddle](/card/33033) helps us trigger it more often and should be kept in mind throughout.

- [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) + [Thruster Boots](/card/16039) - More THW means more damage from [Befuddle](/card/33033), and that's where these upgrades come in. Mulligan hard for these as top priorities - only [Ingenuity](/card/29027) is higher priority, and even that is arguable.

- [C.I.T.T.](/card/17021) - Spend two resources, ready up. When your upgrades have gotten your THW up to 4? This is a great card that then gives you a minimum of 8 threat removal a turn. Combine it with [Befuddle](/card/33033)? And now you have a minimum of 8 minion damage - enough to ensure most of the toughest minions are defeated and trigger Rocket's "Murdered You!" ability.

- [I've Got a Plan](/card/16030) - The beauty of this card alongside [Befuddle](/card/33033) is that [Befuddle](/card/33033) turns that +1 THW into +1 damage. It's not the most efficient combo in the world, but it's very convenient. Combine it with [C.I.T.T.](/card/17021) for maximum value.

- [Professor X](/card/32019) - The Professor is obviously a powerhouse card on its, and confuses are especially good for Rocket to help him go alter-ego without the villain scheming (and so use his "Tinkering" alter-ego ability without worry), but the good Professor also loves [Befuddle](/card/33033). No threat left on the main scheme? Slap [Befuddle](/card/33033) on a minion and turn Professor X into a two-wheeled battering ram of death, effectively giving him 3 ATK against the minion!
 
<hr>
#### **Other Cards**
<hr>
- Basic Allies/[The Power in All of Us](/card/13024) - These are one of the most powerful groups of cards in the game, and Rocket is one of their best users with access to both the coveted Genius trait as well as Guardian. The card draw from [Nick Fury](/card/01084), [Moon Girl](/card/28018) and [Ironheart](/card/13018) is an excellent way to increase your chance of seeing [Befuddle](/card/33033) at the same time as a minion being in play, as well as finding your THW upgrades early. 

- [Gamora](/card/19020) - A great ally in terms of value, just beware that your deck runs few events and you risk discarding half your deck. However, when our key cards - such as [Befuddle](/card/33033) or [Nick Fury](/card/01084) - are in our discard pile? Speeding through our deck to shuffle them back in becomes an advantage!

- [Groot](/card/16047) + [Mockingbird](/card/01083) - While [Professor X](/card/32019) can stop two villain activations, so too can these allies which makes them key parts of your defensive strategy. While [Groot](/card/16047) risks being annihilated in one hit on Expert, particularly against certain villains, he will usually survive an attack - I then recommend using his ATK and/or THW until he is down to 1 hp, then defending again. On Standard, he can often simply defend 3+ times in a row.

- [Plan B](/card/27024) - Plan B is a great way to spend excess cards in hand, such as when you draw multiple ["Think Fast!"](/card/19031) or [Befuddle](/card/33033)s in one hand with no way to use them. The C.I.T.T. is also good for this, but Plan B should not be underestimated on a hero who loves softening up minions.

- ["Think Fast!"](/card/19031) - This card might as well be one of Rocket's own cards. If you're playing him in Justice, you want it! Going alter-ego is always worth it when you can use his "Tinkering" alter-ego ability! While [Sonic Rifle](/card/20015) is technically better value per confuse, it's a lot less flexible to play and takes up your coveted Restricted slots for your weapons. And let's not forget about the theme of the deck, to baffle and bewilder your enemies!

<hr>
#### **Strategy**:
<hr>
Use [Befuddle](/card/33033) to deal with minions whenever possible after setting up your THW upgrades - whether this means outright defeating them, or softening them up so that your weapons can finish them off. You generally always want to try and trigger "Murdered You!" if you can keep the excess damage down to 1 (and often even at 2!).

With [Befuddle](/card/33033) dealing a significant amount of damage to minions, your weapons are freed up to finish them off or lay into the villain. Remember to try and save [Particle Cannon](/card/16036) to get the last hit on minions where possible! This should give you more than enough damage for most scenarios in solo play, and make you a significant contributor to damage in multiplayer.

With a potential THW of 4, multiple ways to ready, and a suite of great allies to remove threat ([Moon Girl](/card/28018), [Nick Fury](/card/01084), [Professor X](/card/32019))? Threat removal should never be an issue in solo play. In multiplayer, you may run into troubles at 3-4 player count. Remind your other players that this deck is more of an all-rounder than a threat-removal specialist, preferably before the game, so they can choose appropriate heroes and decks to support the team's threat control.

While Rocket is a 9hp and 1 DEF hero, your array of excellent allies and ample access to Confused should give you a rock-solid defense. As mentioned before, [Professor X](/card/32019), [Mockingbird](/card/01083) and [Groot](/card/16047) can usually block multiple villain activations! And whenever there's a confuse, be it from [Professor X](/card/32019) or ["Think Fast!"](/card/19031), you'll want to duck into alter-ego.

Due to the great value from basic allies and the ample amount of confuse, you'll likely find yourself with an excess of allies from time to time. In solo play, you shouldn't hesitate to use their last hp on using an ATK or THW if it's helpful to you. Blocking with allies is great value, but one of the strength of allies is their flexibility. In multiplayer, however, you might even find yourself regularly defending other players!

<hr>
#### **Alternative Cards:**
<hr>

- For 3-4 player, consider bringing [Making an Entrance](/card/20013) and extra copies of [Overwatch](/card/30019). 
- [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091) is a great card in general, though with various sources of card draw I've yet to find it necessary despite how easy [The Power in All of Us](/card/13024) makes it to play. Still, this is a great card - especially for multiplayer.
- For allies, [Spider-Man](/card/13019) is a great card that always comes in useful. [Vivian](/card/29024) also has some great uses depending on the villain and modulars!
- [Flora and Fauna](/card/16020) is a handy card, and while I prefer consistent cards that are always available to use, this card can give you a lot of charges if [Groot](/card/16047) is in play.
- And lastly, but certainly not least, [Under Surveillance](/card/06031) is a great option against villains with low threat-threshold main schemes or only 1 main scheme.

<hr>

**Good luck and have fun!**
<hr>

name: Acupuncture
description_md:
So maybe taking a little damage is good for you? 

Although Wolverine does not have any tech upgrades himself, I thought there was still a good synergy with [Repurpose](/card/31016) and [Energy Barrier](/card/05017). Once you have [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) out you can tune the damage you take from minion attacks to ensure you get the draws without taking too much. 

So basically you want to get [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) out and leave a couple of minions with low-ish attack to trigger extra draws. Wolverine can easily out-heal a few.

For villain attacks you will need to defend with allies at least some, if not most of the time. It does depend on scenario a bit, but for tougher villains you can end up with too much damage to out-heal. Especially if you get extra attack encounter cards. [Nightcrawler](/card/32011) helps here, as you can decide whether to use his ability after seeing the boost cards.

I did feel that it needed extra resources so added both [The X-Jet](/card/36023) and [Helicarrier](/card/01092), getting at least one of those out does help. You also want to prioritise playing your [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) cards.

Then, the other part of the deck comes with [Repurpose](/card/31016). Leave your [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) with 1 counter for when you want to use it. When combined with [Jubilee](/card/35003) and extra readies from [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016) you can good amounts of damage. 

After you have set up a bit you want to avoid switching to alter-ego, which should be easy enough given all of the healing. Sometimes I do like to switch just before I want to play [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) though, to get one heal up to near full health (you can play it while in alter-ego, it only discards when going from hero to alter-ego). 

[Professor X](/card/32019) is still useful even though you are avoiding alter-ego. Early on you can flip and the confuse really makes that safer. Then, later on you can always use the other ability to ready Wolverine again. It can even be useful to confuse the villain in case they scheme from an encounter card ability.

There are a few ways to deal with threat, one being [Repurpose](/card/31016) itself, which can boost your thwart. I added [Hit and Run](/card/18020) for this,  it worked better than expected for the early game. It was super useful being able to use [Wolverine's Claws](/card/35002) to pay for a bit of threat removal. The extra 2 damage also helps when dealing with 5-6 health minions. 

Hope you have fun with the build!

name: Stabby Justice
description_md:
Wolverine comes with plenty of damage from his hero cards, so pairing with justice gives a nicely balanced deck. When I saw that [Track by Scent](/card/35011) was basically a better [Clear the Area](/card/04049) I had to make another justice deck with [One Way or Another](/card/30017), 

So the main part of the strategy is of course to draw out side schemes, then gain plenty of benefits by defeating them. To deal with thwarting I have added [Multitasking](/card/15013) and [Clear the Area](/card/04049), which work well for solo play. 

There is a large payoff for defeating the side schemes here, in addition to the draws you get from [Track by Scent](/card/35011). First, [Chance Encounter](/card/26034) allows you to search for the super-useful [Jubilee](/card/35003) ally. After boosting the damage you can then ready Wolverine again by triggering [Justice Served](/card/22014) or using [Utopia](/card/33020). With this you end up with high damage output as well as high thwart!

For defence you can rely on a few cheap allies and Wolverines naturally high healing. One thing to note is that I just put [Weapon X](/card/35022) to have a target for [Forge](/card/36022). I generally just use his ability as an extra resource.

I built this for solo play, but it would work fine in multiplayer with a couple of small changes. I would consider swapping the justice events for ones with higher output, such as [For Justice!](/card/01060) or [Crisis Averted](/card/15012) (maybe along with [Overwatch](/card/30019)).

name: Shadowcat Surprise
description_md:
Shadowcat leans into her ability to flip forms regularly and attack often to supercharge herself using Fluid Motion. With all three in play, plus an array of cheap attack events to trigger it, plus Combat Training and Symbiote Suit if you are so inclined, she can get herself up to seven base attack. With Ready to Rumble and Shadowcat Surprise (her event card) she should have no trouble readying to strike at least twice in a turn. Triggering all three Fluid Motions requires good draws but all of her Aggression events are cheap which helps her play three attack events and potentially have something else to do.


Symbiote Suit, Colossus, and Shadow and Steel are all optional cards for this deck. Shadow and Steel is a good card so worth trying to pull off, which requires Colossus if you're not teaming up with him as a hero. Symbiote Suit gives you that extra attack to pull of seven, but six is still good. The other benefit is the extra hand size which increases the odds of being able to trigger all Fluid Motions in a turn. With multiple ready options she is one who might get enough benefit from it to make the extra Encounter card worth it.

name: Shadowcat Can Take a Hit
description_md:
You know what happens when Shadowcat defends in Phased form? Nothing, she can't take damage. What's the best way to exploit that? Try to be in Phased form and defending any time she would take damage. To pull that off you need a lot of Defense event cards with the Defense keyword that don't trigger off of you already being the defender. Things like Never Back Down and Desperate Defense are out. You don't care about boosting your defense stat afterall. In are Defiance, Powerful Punch, Jump Flip, and Side Step. These cards are intended to mitigate things when you take damage. Which they will do by making you the defender and therefore immune to damage. When you're not in Phased form to start, they'll do their regular effect, mitigating your damage, and then flipping you into Phased form. Defiance and Powerful Punch can further be used to make Shadowcat the defender without needing to exhaust.


To really make this build feel like an exploit, we have Flow Like Water, Dauntless, and Electrostatic Armor. Any time she defense with one of her event cards, she's dishing three damage back out to her attacker. Those don't need to exhaust so if you can defend multiple times, you get to dish that damage back multiple times.


The biggest weakness of this build will be getting all of your upgrades into play. You're geared around blowing your load during the Villains phase, which leaves you very few cards to play on your turn. Until you get some of the resource generating cards out (X-Jet, Unflappable, Nerves of Steel) you're paying with cards in hand. If you're not careful you could get into a loop where you're not building up your kit and not defending very well.

name: Geo's Captain S.H.I.E.L.D.
description_md: After my buddy first had the desire of running a "minion-mancer" I first came across this site to find the answer. While we're assembling Journeyman's "50 Shades of X-Men" deck for X-Men tribal, or contemplating Captain America for Avengers tribal, I decided on the totally unoriginal idea of mindlessly throwing every single card that said S.H.I.E.L.D. in one deck for S.H.I.E.L.D. tribal. I am ignorantly choosing Captain Marvel to helm this deck for no other reason than she has [Energy Absorption](/card/01014) for production which I imagine will allow her to better play her S.H.I.E.L.D. cards. Running two [Helicarrier](/card/01092)s, because we can only field one but it's nice to see it faster. And forget [Agent Coulson](/card/08011) - we're not running any Preparations.

name: Roughneck Regenerator
description_md:
The longer Wolverine stays out, the more consistent damage output.

[Momentum Shift](/card/09016), and [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016) are the key to keeping Wolverine topped off and putting out consistent damage. [Hard Knocks](/card/19016), [Polaris](/card/32012), [Tackle](/card/05015), and [The Night Nurse](/card/09019) will help with status effect game.

Running Mutant Genesis with some friends playing Phoenix (Justice) and Quicksilver (Aggression), so popping [Honorary X-Men](/card/33035) to potentially benefit Quicksilver, or even just provide a strength resource for [Tackle](/card/05015) or [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016). Then keeping with the themes here, [Professor X](/card/32019) and [The X-Jet](/card/32020) are in this play for their general decent usability. Would consider switching out these cards for something like 3 [Energy Barrier](/card/05017) or 3 [Med Team](/card/01080) cards.

Running as a Brawler in the campaign. For my option to add an Aggression Upgrade and Event, I'm incorporating [Combat Training](/card/01057) and a [Clobber](/card/18012). On my aggression play with Wolverine, I found these two cards to be probably my two favorite. Extra basic attack with Wolvy's already solid basic attack (along with [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004)) and a free play of Clobber using [Wolverine's Claws](/card/35002) should be fun.

Wolverine is a lot of fun, but more so the longer you can just keep him in hero mode doing work.

name: Venom Impenetrable
description_md:
*"Parasite? Bad? Can't be bad. Wasn't bad with Flash. Fought with heroes. Was a hero. Trained another symbiote. Got to learn. Got to teach. Flash called me partner. Was never afraid like Spider-Man" Venom Symbiote: Venom Vol 1 #154* I wanted to build a deck where it will be almost impossible to hit Venom. And I came up with this one. The who idea of the deck is for, after set-up, Venom to defence against *villain*'s attacks with [Grasping Tendrils](/card/20003), and [Rockslide](/card/33013) will take care of any other defending needed against minions and 3rd villain attacks. **Allies** - 3 *Guardian* allies to cycle through; [Gamora](/card/19020), [Martinex](/card/21065) and [Rocket Raccoon](/card/16019) - 1 X-Men ally to be used as a permanent support card.
    - Combining [Rockslide](/card/33013) with [Protective Training](/card/32013) means 9HP and 1 *Retaliate*. Add [Hangar Bay](/card/36035) to the equation and Rockslide can defend twice in one turn and still stay alive. This is perfect in decks with a lot of minions, or if you do not draw [Grasping Tendrils](/card/20003).
**Events** [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016) is the only event added in addition to the events of the core deck. It serves two purposes. It will health *Venom*, and Venom loses at least one HP each turn thanks to *Symbiotic Bond*, and it will ready Venom to take full advantage of [Venom's Pistol](/card/20010). **Supports** - [Hangar Bay](/card/36035), [CITT](/card/17021) and [Med Team](/card/01080) are in this deck to support [Rockslide](/card/33013). Of course, in dire times, [Med Team](/card/01080) and [CITT](/card/17021) can be used for *Venom* as well. - [Knowhere](/card/17022) and [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091) are cards drawing power. -[Helicarrier](/card/01092) is to allow the play of more events each turn. **Upgrades** Here things get complicated. The protection upgrades in the deck are situational and will allow once every 2 turns to have a bigger hand and play more cards. --**Here's how it works**-- - [Electrostatic Armor](/card/10031) and [Unflappable](/card/09020) will trigger only when you defend, and for *Unflappable*, you must also take no damage. [Spider-Sense](/card/20009) will activate only when the *Villain* attacks you.
    - Option 1; when the *Villain* attacks, if you have [Grasping Tendrils](/card/20003) in your hand, you use it and you satisfy the condition, you have *defended* without taking any damage. - Option 2; you can defend using *Venom*'s 2 defence and still trigger at least *Electrostatic Armor* and then ready *Venom* with [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016). - Option 3; if there is a minion on the board, and you have enough HP to survive two attacks, let the *Villain* attack you, and then use *Venom* to defend against the minion. This way you will still trigger both [Spider-Sense](/card/20009) and [Unflappable](/card/09020).
- [Dauntless](/card/16016) should be an easy one to achieve, even while constantly using *Symbiotic Bond*, as [Endurance](/card/05023) and [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) will give you additional *13 Hit Point*, and with [Down Time](/card/05033) and [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191), *Flash Thompson* has a recovery of 7, plus [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016), plus [Med Team](/card/01080). Long story-short, this is the deck. Very fun execution and plenty of creative ways to mess around with the *Villain*.

name: Spider-Tank
description_md:
Cheap protection deck for Spider-Man. The goal is to defend without taking damage (helped by lot of events) to draw 2 more cards per turn.
Easy to survive but hard to kill enemy quickly.

This deck will better fit in team game than solo play.

name: Ghost-Spider - Into the Spider-Verse
description_md:
This is a Spider-Verse protection deck proposition.
Défense is really good but the deck don't lack offensive options with the help of all the Spider-Man and all the ready actions we have.

name: Mystic Logistics
description_md:
There are probably loads of decks using Scarlet Witch with the S.H.I.E.L.D. supports already, but I found this build really consistent so thought I would post it. Who knew the best way to predict the future was just planning?

The main idea is to use [Global Logistics](/card/27043) to manipulate the encounter deck to get what you want from [Hex Bolt](/card/15004) and [Molecular Decay](/card/15005).  [Hex Bolt](/card/15004) can be tuned to do whatever you need. Once you have a decent setup, [Hex Bolt](/card/15004) and [Molecular Decay](/card/15005) provide plenty of damage to finish the scenario.

The Mystic-specific cards along with [Chaos Magic](/card/15003) help to speed-up the setup. The extra draws from [The Sorcerer Supreme](/card/09026) and [Spiritual Meditation](/card/15019) mean you will see it more often. 

I found that [Homeland Intervention](/card/27042) was not necessary, there is plenty of thwart already. You can switch to alter-ego quite safely once you have [Counterintelligence](/card/08017) and [Under Surveillance](/card/06031) out.

For defence it relies on allies with the occasional [Magic Shield](/card/15008) for defence. 

One nice interaction is that [Agent 13](/card/27046) can ready [Helicarrier](/card/01092) with her ability. 

I tested this in solo and it should do well in any scenario. It doesn't rely much on confuse, so even Stalwart / Steady villains should be fine.

name: Shadowcat-basic pride
description_md:
Wanted to build a basic only x-men deck and I felt shaddowcat was a good fit
While we wait for gambit to add xmen education and mutant education to come into the card pool.

Gambit would probably be a better fit for a basic only build but untill we get him I felt like giving it a crack with what we had.
This deck has alot of options considering basic only felt a bit limiting, still a fun one though 

Going alter-ego:
1.flip forms so you can stay in the phased side to take no damage and ready to rumble after you defend and flip to solid to ready her

2. Use kitty's room to draw or heal combined with endurance your not worried about her health getting to low .

3. meditation to play upgrades/supports/allies and honorary x-men to ready her
Also you can use the x-jet in alter ego with this attached
Weapon x can dig up her key cards to then play with meditation.

4. Cerebro to find the allies and with prof x out you can search the whole deck for any you like

With so many upgrades and supports means once you've set up, the deck is thinned out and you can see her cards more often
Her ability to thawt past crisis icons and a massive amount of ready helps with not needing to stay on top of threat as much as you normaly would.
(She can remove 4 threat from main alot of the time this way)

There are plenty of allies to help with chip damage and thwarting so not much chump blocking as her phased means your normally quite healthy through the game and can heal back up real quickly

You will be flipping to alter-ego every other turn as to use all the combos and stay in phased form.
Has been real fun tinkering away at this brew can prob use a few adjustments so feel free to let me know any ideas you would bring to it
Hope you enjoy
