name: "Encounter Cards, I Choose You!" - SHIELD Star-Lord
description_md:
<hr>
**Wanna be the very best, like no one ever was?**

...Well, good luck! I can't help you there. What I can say is that [Global Logistics](/card/27043) allows Star-Lord to not only see but CHOOSE his own encounter cards. And, for a hero that draws a lot of encounter cards, that's pretty neat.

Also? New card [Command Center](/card/35032) loves [Leader of the Guardians](/card/17009).
<hr>
**If you like this deck, feel free to give it a ❤ ! Thank you!**
<hr>

_Picture the scene._

It was a rainy Wednesday night. There I was, minding my own business browsing the internet, and people were discussing the best SHIELD heroes. "Star-Lord," I think to myself with a smirk. But as I read and read and read, nobody - absolutely nobody - is talking about SHIELD Star-Lord. 

My smugness turns to fear.

Quickly, I open marvelcdb and search published decks! To my horror, there is only one Star-Lord SHIELD deck out there I could find! But it doesn't include [Global Logistics](/card/27043). Worse, only one published single Star-Lord deck even uses [Global Logistics](/card/27043) - but it's not a full SHIELD deck.

Horror turns to dismay - but not all hope is lost. Through the power of collecting all 8 gym badges, I now present to you the lord of SHIELD himself.

<hr>
#### **Why SHIELD?**
<hr>

1) SHIELD's weakness? Slow setup. Star-Lord's strength? Quick setup by taking an encounter card to reduce costs.

2) Star-Lord's weakness? He takes extra encounter cards. SHIELD's strength? You can pick and choose your encounter cards with [Global Logistics](/card/27043).

Their strengths both compliment each other and cover their weaknesses. This extends to the fact that SHIELD allies generally have a good THW stat which Star-Lord can enhance by making them all Guardians and [Leader of the Guardians](/card/17009). Likewise, where SHIELD lacks damage, Star-Lord has buckets of damage.

I've actually been playing this deck for the last few days and had a ton of fun with it. At either 1 or 2 player, I have used this deck to beat:

- Expert Drang
- Expert Loki
- Expert Sinister Six
- Expert Mutagen Formula + Mr. Hyde
- Expert Klaw  

While this deck can do fine in 3-4 player, be aware that it will need help thwarting and that [Command Center](/card/35032) becomes much harder to reliably trigger. Consider swapping it for another [Overwatch](/card/30019).

<hr>
#### **Professor Oak's Laboratory**
<hr>
Here we are at the start of the game! Your aim should be to get [Global Logistics](/card/27043) online immediately. This means you need a low-cost, low-value target to exhaust for it. [Field Agent](/card/27044) is the ideal target, but [Surveillance Team](/card/01064) is good too - especially if you can bring it into play through [Monica Chang](/card/27040).

Aside from [Field Agent](/card/27044) or [Monica Chang](/card/27040), your top mulligan priorities are [Helicarrier](/card/01092), [Knowhere](/card/17022), [Star-Lord's Helmet](/card/17010), and [Leader of the Guardians](/card/17009). [Nick Fury](/card/01084) also makes for a strong opening if you cannot find any of those named upgrades/supports - he can effectively extend your mulligan to another three cards. And, if you find [Element Gun](/card/17007) in your initial hand, use the mulligan to discard it immediately.

If in solo, I try to prioritize playing an [Element Gun](/card/17007) on Turn 1, especially against minion-heavy scenarios. 3 damage on demand is a strong tool for Justice to have. After its initial cost, it's a Turn the Tide you can trigger at any time with piercing ~ 1 card=3 damage. Star-Lord's other sources of damage can be risky before you're ready to [Global Logistics](/card/27043).

In 2-4 player, you can lean on your other player(s) for damage and focus fully on setting up before worrying about your weapons.

If you can play a cheap ally such as [Ironheart](/card/13018) or [Quake](/card/08012), alongside [Element Gun](/card/17007) or any of the other named cards, you're doing well. In short? If you can end up with an ally, an element gun, and a support/upgrade in play? You've had the perfect Turn 1. It won't always be possible, but you should always aim for it.

If you are wondering where [Homeland Intervention](/card/27042) is? With these allies and [Leader of the Guardians](/card/17009), there is already more than enough thwarting to handle things solo and in most 2-player scenarios. Adding more would be excessive, and also require room for more SHIELD supports, taking away from Star-Lord's affinity with allies. In 3-4 player, you definitely want to look into them at that point.

Likewise, we only run 2 [Surveillance Team](/card/01064)s for the same reason. We don't need more, and ideally we only want to play them through [Monica Chang](/card/27040) who we're unlikely to play three times in one match. And if you did, it's almost inevitable that you would end the game with a bunch of unspent counters. We want to avoid sinking resources into upgrades that are unlikely to pay off, and make sure our hand has some quicker-tempo options.

<hr>
#### **"Encounter Cards, I choose you!"**
<hr>
Generally, a solid game plan is to try and play at least 1 ally per turn when possible. Especially with [Knowhere](/card/17022) out. If you have a [Global Logistics](/card/27043) in hand, try to at least play one of those too. Especially if the ally you play lacks the SHIELD trait, just to make sure you can trigger [Sky-Destroyer](/card/27055).

[Global Logistics](/card/27043) should always target the villain deck. Organizing the order of the cards you find is the hardest part of this deck, and should be done carefully. Check if you or any other players are going to run out of cards in your decks and thus take an encounter card while drawing your new hand of cards at the end of the turn. 

Decide on whether you're going to use "What could go wrong?" or even a [Daring Escape](/card/17003) before you put the encounter cards back. Some are weak as boost cards but strong when revealed as encounter cards, and some are the other way around. You really want to set Shadow of the Past or Advance to be boost cards.

It might sound obvious, but if you plan to take an additional encounter card, put the least-bad encounter card on top of the villain deck. Then think through which of the remaining cards will be boost cards and which will be an encounter card. 

In solo, you can plan ahead to your next turn. In multiplayer, [Global Logistics](/card/27043) will let you set up boost cards more than encounter cards - make sure to coordinate with your Protection player if you have one! Make it easy to trigger their Unflappable.

<hr>
#### **Challenging the League**
<hr>
Once you've assembled your team of 6 SHIELD agents and leveled them up- Er..- I mean- Once you've gotten a good amount of upgrades/supports down and have control of the game, it's time to turn on the damage.

Remember throughout the game that [Field Agent](/card/27044) is best used on [Agent 13](/card/27046), with [Agent Coulson](/card/08011) also a great target. [Surveillance Team](/card/01064) is a great tool to chip down side-schemes until an ally can defeat it cleanly and trigger [Command Center](/card/35032). Just remember to keep 1 charge on at least one of [Field Agent](/card/27044) and [Surveillance Team](/card/01064) so [Global Logistics](/card/27043) always has a great target.

Speaking of [Agent 13](/card/03002), she is best known for readying [Helicarrier](/card/01092) - but [Sky-Destroyer](/card/27055) also makes a great choice if you know you're playing another SHIELD card this turn. Often, you will only manage to have one of those expensive supports out and she can make great uses of either of them.

[Spider-Man](/card/13019) and [Nick Fury](/card/01084) are your all-purpose tools. Don't be afraid to choose the damage option on either of them if that's what you need. Mathematically, Nick Fury gets the best value from choosing to draw you 3 cards, but if you have a nasty minion in front of you? It's often better to guarantee defeating it with his damage rather than draw three cards and find no solution.

Don't underestimate [Nova Prime](/card/17002) while in Justice either. You have a few sources of damage, but you won't be able to trigger [Command Center](/card/35032) and [Sky-Destroyer](/card/27055) every single turn without fail or in efficient ways. Sometimes you need [Nova Prime](/card/17002) to do your dirty work and simply delete that minion from existence!

[Element Gun](/card/17007)s, [Command Center](/card/35032) and [Sky-Destroyer](/card/27055) are great at chipping away at the villain, and a few of your allies also have great damage. Also, if your allies have the threat handled, Star-Lord's 2 ATK is another great tool in your arsenal. 

Defeating the villain's initial stage should be a gradual process at a moderate pace. And then? Then it's time to let Star-Lord do what Star-Lord does best.

Annihilate them with [Daring Escape](/card/17003)s and [Sliding Shot](/card/17005). The damage isn't as explosive as it can be in Aggression or Leadership, so make sure you do the math and can defeat the villain before you take 3+ encounter cards! [Global Logistics](/card/27043) can only do so much!

<hr>
**Good luck and have fun!**
<hr>

name: Colossus Stunbot Multiplayer
description_md: Overview: [Pheromones](/card/04036) is generally considered to be a very strong card, and [Steel Fist](/card/32008) is basically Pheromones that also does 5 damage and draws you a card (thanks to [Iron Will](/card/32004)). This deck focuses on playing Steel Fist every turn to keep the villain permanently stunned and confused, and also pumps out strong sustained damage every turn. It also excels at controlling big minions due to high damage and sheer abundance of stuns. The idea is to thin your deck by playing numerous Upgrades and Supports, and then use [Plan of Attack](/card/18013) to reliably play multiple [Steel Fist](/card/32008)s and/or [Drop Kick](/card/10014)s every turn. Due to Colosuss's tremendously high economy curve, you will be able play multiple of these powerhouse cards most turns, and activate [Fluid Motion](/card/28016) while doing so. You will then often have resources left over to play [Limitless Stamina](/card/31023) (or sometimes [Bulletproof Protector](/card/32009)) to ready yourself in order to hit multiple times with your 5 or 6 ATK. As far as deck-thinning goes, Colosuss has access to plenty of juicy Upgrades to help him make the most of his thinned-out deck. This deck's value is comprised of, primarily, huge amounts of villain control and sustained damage, and secondarily, lots of support for your teammates, especially X-Men (thanks to the [The X-Jet](/card/32020)). The deck absolutely shuts down non-Stalwart villains that rely on big activations, and handles beefy minions well due to the sheer amount of control and damage. With your huge resource curve, you will have no qualms with spending most of your supports on teammates every turn. The deck cannot cope with large minion swarms such as Ultron - scenarios with many minions will simply burn your Tough statuses too quickly unless another Hero is mopping them up every turn. This deck requires about 2 turns of setup, minimum, before it provides significant value, and is vulnerable to bad draws - specifically, bottom-decking [Iron Will](/card/32004) is very painful, although [Piotr's Studio](/card/32003) and [Weapon X](/card/35022) help alleviate this. Set up: You'll want to get [Iron Will](/card/32004) on the board as soon as possible - this is Colossus's biggest enabler, and encourages you to liberally spend your Tough statuses to activate kickers on his powerful events. Don't be afraid to burn all of your toughs and go into the villain phase unarmored- with 14 health and 4 REC, you can freely tank villain attacks without much concern. The extra basic THW might be nice in a pinch, but your activations are generally better spent on your much higher basic ATK. Mulligan hard for this card, and then cycle as fast as possible until you get it - don't forget to consider playing [Plan of Attack](/card/18013) in your first cycle even if you don't plan on playing an Attack, simply to thin one Event out of Iron Will's way. [Piotr's Studio](/card/32003) will most likely be second on your list of priority supports, especially if you mulligan into it - you should play it and use it right away to speed up the search for Iron Will. Colossus HAS to flip down once he runs out of Toughs, since he has no baseline way to regenrate them from scratch in Hero form. Luckily, confusing the villain via Steel Fist covers your flip, and the Studio is a fantastic way to hunt for more Steel Fists when you start your turn in Alter Ego, which should be often. [Weapon X](/card/35022) fulfills the same function at a 1-health cost - and Colossus has more than enough health to spare. Unfortunately, being Tough prevents you from using Weapon X, so try to shed your Toughs before flipping down. Having both of these Supports in play is extremely strong, and virtually guarantees huge plays every turn you start in Alter Ego. [Titanium Muscles](/card/32005) should be your next priority; it will almost always be worth at least one as a Hero resource generator, and often it will be worth two. It also includes a free [Combat Training](/card/01057). This card, combined with some or all of the other resource generators in this deck, gives you access to an insanely high resource curve, allowing you to play almost every [Steel Fist](/card/32008) and [Drop Kick](/card/10014) you see with ease. [Organic Steel](/card/32006) is very important to Colosuss's flow, and it's almost always a good idea to play the one you get from your Setup ability. Once Iron Will is out, this card will essentially provide two card draws over its life as well as two Toughs, providing huge value, but the power of two Toughs for 3 ER should not be overlooked even before Iron Will shows up, since it buys you so much time to set up. [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019) is shockingly effective in this deck. You can trigger it off Attack Events, and you will often be rich enough to do so. It plays very well with [Limitless Stamina](/card/31023), which can allow you proc Jarnbjorn twice or be used as fuel for it. At 1 cost, [Deft Focus](/card/16024) is easy to get in play, and very quickly pays for itself with no fewer than eight high-value targets that you will see in every cycle ([Steel Fist](/card/32008), [Organic Steel](/card/32006) and [Limitless Stamina](/card/31023)).It will usually make sense to play this first if you draw it alongside [Iron Will](/card/32004) or [Titanium Muscles](/card/32005), since it will help pay for those cards as well. [Martial Prowess](/card/10018) plays very nice with [Drop Kick](/card/10014) and can also help with [Steel Fist](/card/32008). It's quite satisfying to play a [Drop Kick](/card/10014), complete with kicker, using just this and [Titanium Muscles](/card/32005). [Fluid Motion](/card/28016) - you may be surprised to see two of this card, but playing two Attacks in one turn with this deck is actually fairly trivial once you are set up, even with only 6 Attacks in the deck, all costing either 2 or 3. This is thanks to your high resource curve and to supporting Events like [Plan of Attack](/card/18013), not to mention the fact that all of these attacks can draw a card when played. With two [Fluid Motion](/card/28016)s, [Titanium Muscles](/card/32005), and [Combat Training](/card/01057), your basic attack will hit 6 if you play 2 Attacks. [The X-Jet](/card/32020) rounds out your resource curve, and can be used in many ways - spent on cards, stripping attachments, proccing [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019), or used on allied X-Men players. [Helicarrier](/card/01092) is generally less flexible than the X-Jet, but it also plays nicely with [Drop Kick](/card/10014) and provides non-X-Men specific support. [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091) goes a very long way towards smoothing out awkward draws, which are a weakness of this deck - extremely high resource curve on top of small hand size complete with nine 0-cost cards will do that. Playing this requires a lot of breathing room but the reward is extremely high, assuming you don't lose it right away to [Overwhelming Force](/card/24052). This also functions well as a support card for your allies. [Hand Cannon](/card/16046) is a solid way to round out your minion control, and can get out of the way to at least temporarily thin your deck. It also has a on it, and so plays well with [Drop Kick](/card/10014). [Unshakable](/card/31024) is cheap and will block the first Stun that hits you, and can potentially block more in long games. Keep in mind that you can play this while Stunned and then attack as normal. [Throg](/card/25014) is here to block for your teammates. He is probably the most efficient Ally in the game assuming you are engaged with a minion. Events: Not much more to be said about [Steel Fist](/card/32008) at this point. Cancelling ~two villain activations while advancing the win condition AND cycling your deck is simply insane. You can make the argument that you're really only cancelling one activation since you lose a Tough, and that is often true, but is frequently mitigated by cards like [Bulletproof Protector](/card/32009) and [Organic Steel](/card/32006). Both of these cards will enable you to play Steel Fist, with kicker, and still end the phase with at least one Tough. [Drop Kick](/card/10014) is the other star in this deck. It provides less control and damage compared to Steel Fist, and costs 1 more, but it plays well with [Titanium Muscles](/card/32005), and including three of them doubles the number of targets for [Plan of Attack](/card/18013). Having three of these alongside your three Steels Fists provides extremely good control, allowing you to handle beefy minions and Steady villains alike. [Plan of Attack](/card/18013) is here to find the above cards, and further rewards Colossus for starting his turn in AE. [Made of Rage](/card/32007) has a fairly obvious use case. You most likely won't play this often, but it can come in handy when trying to kill a big minion or rush down the villain. [Bulletproof Protector](/card/32009) is a card that you will almost always just play instantly when you see it. With [Iron Will](/card/32004) out, this is a free Tough and cycle. The option to use it to ready is rarely needed, but the added flexibility is nice. [Armor Up](/card/32010) is a great card in the first cycle; if you draw this in Hero form, there is little reason not to flip to AE before ending your turn. This will net you a Tough and help you cycle your deck faster to find upgrades. Once you have [Piotr's Studio](/card/32003) and [Weapon X](/card/35022) out, you should pause and think before playing this card, since it will rob you of your powerful AE Supports when your turn starts. [Smash the Problem](/card/25019) is here for emergency threat control. It's not often you will want to play this card, but being able to remove a net 3-4 threat in a pinch is very nice. Questions you may have: Q: No double resources aside from [Strength](/card/01090)? A: Yep. This deck is capable of producing NINE extra resources per turn if all your Supports are out. Double resources just get in the way, aside from this one, which can be used to efficiently play [Drop Kick](/card/10014) and helps you set up. Q: No allies? A: Colossus just doesn't need 'em. Chumps ain't his style. Throg gets a pass for his ability to efficiently defend your teammates. If you're playing Solo, you will probably have to take more allies for threat control. Q: Does the deck struggle against Steady villains? A: Nope. It actually feels awesome to play this deck vs Steady - the feeling of playing [Steel Fist](/card/32008) twice to fully stunfuse a Steady villain is absolute bliss. Q: Does the deck struggle against Stalwart villains? A: Yep.

name: QuickDraw McClaw
description_md:
There are a lot of good Wolverine Aggression builds out there, Fluid Motion, Confuse+Weapon X, Fastball Special ATK Stack...but not enough revolve around [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005)
## **Toe to Toe, Claw to Claw** This deck is very simple: - Get out **[Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005)** - Summon a bunch of 1-2 ATK minions with **[Angela](/card/18011)** and **[Looking for Trouble](/card/16043)** - Farm them for card draw with **["Bring It!"](/card/19030)** and [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) The real tech here is [Toe to Toe](/card/32046). I had initially written it off since Wolverine wants to conserve his health for Claws, but a quick number breakdown shows that it is quite efficient! **Consider the sequence**: - Play **[Toe to Toe](/card/32046)** with **[Wolverine's Claws](/card/35002)** for net -1 health - Minion attacks you for net -1 or -2 health - Draw a card off [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) - Deal 5 damage to minion, likely defeating it Net Result: **5 damage for 0ER and 2-3 health** **Compare to**: - [Berserker Barrage](/card/35008) 4 damage for 1ER and 2 health - [Slice and Dice](/card/27060) 6 damage for 1ER and 3 health - [Lunging Strike](/card/35010) 8 damage for 1ER and 3 health - [Clobber](/card/18012) 3 damage for 0ER and 2 health I value [Toe to Toe](/card/32046) being *no cost from hand*, basically replacing [Berserker Barrage](/card/35008) and [Slice and Dice](/card/35009) for me! If you took a hit from that minion in the villain phase and drew a card off ["Bring It!"](/card/19030), you've now drawn 3 cards off that minion at the negligible cost of some health! If you count the *Healing Factor* at the start of your turn, any 1 ATK minions are a net 0 change in health and 0 change in ER!
## **Quickdraw McClaw** - Between **[Track by Scent](/card/35011)**, ["Bring It!"](/card/19030), and [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005), this deck has some crazy card draw - Draw 2-3 cards in the villain phase from attacks, another 2-3 from ["Bring It!"](/card/19030), play some [Toe to Toe](/card/32046)s to clear minions for no change in net resources, then [Track by Scent](/card/35011) to clear any schemes and you should *still* have 8-10 cards in hand to mess with - This cycles **[Regenerative Healing](/card/02036)** quickly - All of the card draw gets our allies back fast, meaning we don't need to run as many to guarantee [Utopia](/card/33020) triggers - Sets up [Forge](/card/36022) and any key upgrades quickly
## **Clobber+Jarnbjorn Courtesy of ClassyRobot** - **[Clobber](/card/18012)** is a Wolverine staple, but I'm also including **[Jarnbjorn](/card/06019)** a neat tech I saw in a deck from criminally underrated user, [ClassyRobot](https://marvelcdb.com/user/profile/27264/ClassyRobot) - Play [Clobber](/card/18012) with [Wolverine's Claws](/card/35002) as your first card play, costing 2 health, then return it to hand and spend that same [Clobber](/card/18012) on [Jarnbjorn](/card/06019) - Net result is 5 damage for 1ER and 2 health, slightly worse ER than [Toe to Toe](/card/32046) + [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005), but trades off being able to split the damage up into pockets of 3 and 2 for *having* to be the first thing you do that turn. There are pros and cons to each, but this deck is all about finding efficiency loopholes - Just be careful, [Clobber](/card/18012) can sometimes get in the way of ["Bring It!"](/card/19030), since you want to get the card draw *before* you [Clobber](/card/18012) any minions
## **All the Other Stuff** - [Colossus](/card/35021) and [Throg](/card/25014) help tank the villain - [Forge](/card/36022) finds [The X-Jet](/card/36023) and [Utopia](/card/33020) - [Sunfire](/card/35014) is too generically useful not to include - [Endurance](/card/36026) and [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004) get us to 17 hp to tank as many attacks as possible - [Utopia](/card/36024) + X-Men allies is our primary source of thwarting, but also readies Wolverine for his chunky 6 REC in a pinch (just make sure you ready him before flipping down or after flipping up) - In the event you have to flip down and discard [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005), [Logan's Cabin](/card/35007) can put it back in the deck
## **But Where is X Card?** - No [Fluid Motion](/card/28016) because this Wolverine will be basic thwarting a lot considering he only has [Track by Scent](/card/35011), [Professor X](/card/37017), and [Looking for Trouble](/card/16043) in terms of other thwart - No [Fastball Special](/card/35023) because we have few attack boosts and no way to recur [Colossus](/card/32048) other than turbo draw (though you could include it over a [Clobber](/card/18012)) - No [Psylocke](/card/35013), [Weapon X](/card/35022), or [Honorary X-Men](/card/33035) because we don't want to flip down and lose [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) unless we have to. [Professor X](/card/37017) covers our confuse needs nicely
## **Mulligan** - Number 1 target is **[Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004)**, the extra 4 hp are integral to being able to tank attacks while you set up and cycle [Regenerative Healing](/card/02036) - [Utopia](/card/33020), [The X-Jet](/card/32020), [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) are the economy picks - [Endurance](/card/36026) helps when [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004) is stuck low in the deck - **[Logan's Cabin](/card/35007)** is not a bad early play actually. Wolverine will typically need to flip down at least once early if [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004) isn't out, and Cabin can put [Berserker Frenzy](/card/35005) or [Regenerative Healing](/card/02036) back in the deck (or [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004) if it had to get passed up on)
This deck works best in scenarios that have great minion targets to farm, more difficult minions require cycling [Regenerative Healing](/card/02036) even more. I had a lot of fun with this deck in 3-player games with fellow Marvelcdb users [Schmendrix](https://marvelcdb.com/user/profile/1901/Schmendrix) and [Mikepelf](https://marvelcdb.com/user/profile/11440/Mikepelf), as well as some true solo games!

name: Ant-Man (SCL 13:5)
description_md:
Solo Champions League Season 13 Round 5 - Tower Defense + Streets of Mayhem (01/22/23-02/04/23)
Difficulty: Expert
Hero: Ant-Man, Black Widow, Spectrum, Vision, or Wasp
Aspect: Leadership
Campaign Elements:
+ 3 Damage to Avengers Tower

Build the table with Avengers Tower, Mighty Avengers, and Quincarrier. While also putting down some Quinjets in order to get the high cost allies out. Although  Fury and Professor X aren't avengers they are helpful for card draw and confusing Proxima Midnight respectively. 

Make the Call and Rapid Response are there to make sure you always have an ally there to soak the attacks from the two villains and not worry about the negative effects on the tower (unless you get rain fire as the boost card).

Thanks to VillainTheroy for convincing me to use the quinjet again.

name: SCL S13 R4 Miles Leadership
description_md:
The goal for SCL S13R4 was to get out a minion with high attack early and have them exhaust each turn to control the sand counters. [Wonder Man](/card/03014) for example was great at this. [Moon Girl](/card/28018) was also great for this since I could reliably draw two or three cards from her, giving me a 2-powered ally for cheap. I had one of these two allies on my first turn in all three games. [Inspired](/card/01074) was included to buff up ally attack to remove sand counters asap, but it was only used in my practice games. [Gentle](/card/36016) was also meant to serve this purpose, but I didn't draw him early enough.

Then [Spider-Man](/card/27049) was the MVP of the round. Between [Rapid Response](/card/08031), [Make the Call](/card/01071), and [Across the Spider-Verse](/card/27018), I could reliably keep him in play to give Miles extra activations. It honestly felt too strong.

Beyond that, combinations of Venom Blast and Spider Camouflage ensured Sandman rarely activated against me. I believe I took three total attacks and maybe two scheme activations across all three matches.

Got pretty lucky with my rounds- avoided most of the Sinister Six. Only saw the expert cards as boosts or discarded by surging sands. Ended with completely clear boards in six turns all three games, with 13/11/13 hp on board in the respective rounds

name: Owning the Means of Production
description_md:
![proletariat schmoletariate](https://i.imgur.com/Ak5m5m6.png)
<font size="1">*Colossus' early attempts at flirting were met with mixed results*</font>

Hello comrades! Do you like *receiving the fruits of your labour*? Do you *despair over the impending capitalist collapse that will kill us all if we do not establish socialism*? Me too, comrade. Me too.

**Seize the Means of Production**

Increase your efficiency by thinning your deck and providing other players with tools to create value every turn:

- [Crew Quarters](/card/20029)
- [Down Time](/card/05033)
- [Endurance](/card/05023)
- [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065)
- [Justice Served](/card/22014)
- [Plan B](/card/27024)
- [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022)
- [Sense of Justice](/card/14030)
- [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047)

All of the above cards can be played under any player's control and ideally should be played to other players. This is the ideal setup for a 2-player game, where anything with 1 copy should be given to your partner ([Crew Quarters](/card/20029), [Down Time](/card/05033), [Endurance](/card/05023), [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065), [Sense of Justice](/card/14030)), anything with 2 should be shared equally ([Plan B](/card/27024), [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047)), and anything with 3 copies has enough utility (and discards) that you can simply use them as necessary ([Justice Served](/card/22014), [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022)).

**Work-life Balance**

Remember to keep a good work-life balance by flipping often. [Paint a little](/card/32003), go to the movies with your [girlfriend](/card/32002), just enjoy life comrade. Every time you flip to Alter-Ego, embrace your *Aspiring Artist* abilities and shuffle in all the things that motivate you, like [protecting your loved ones](/card/32010) or fighting [capitalist dogs](/card/32008).

**Power to the Proletariat**

Uncle Karl values hard work and determination. [One Way or Another](/card/22015), you will succeed. You have [Limitless Stamina](/card/31023) and a [Deft Focus](/card/16024) to work until the task is completed, because you are [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022) at the start of each day after a night of quality rest and relaxation.

Work together with your fellow comrades to take shifts. In a 2+ player game, you can use [Steel Fist](/card/32008) almost every round to stun and confuse the villain. With one player in hero form and another in alter-ego, stop two villain activations every round. But there are many other options. [Bulletproof Protector](/card/32009) along with [Limitless Stamina](/card/31023) could leverage your impressive ATK, especially when you are [Made of Rage](/card/32007). Just be sure to flex your [Iron Will](/card/32004), [Organic Steel](/card/32006), and [Titanium Muscles](/card/32005).

You will also help fuel your deck by digging for Side Schemes. Then, will help your fellow comrades help you with [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) and [Sense of Justice](/card/14030) to empower them and [Justice Served](/card/22014) and [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047) to reward them.

If that doesn't work, there's always [Plan B](/card/27024) to help increase efficiency by burning any leftover card in your hand at the end of the round.

**Professional Development**

The future looks bright for hardworking comrades. Earn extra certifications to improve your career prospects with [Mutant Education](/card/37021) and shuffle in your most important pieces even more often; draw an extra card when you have [X-Mansion](/card/32049) in play. Unlock your [X-Gene](/card/38019) to help pay for those strong events, but keep in mind that [Deft Focus](/card/16024) is a priority since it will also help pay for your upgrades. [Moira MacTaggert](/card/38018) is another solid card, especially if you plan to shuffle in [Armor Up](/card/32010). It's a 7-card hand size every round if you can keep it going.

However, not every shareable upgrade is necessary. Many definitely depend on how you and your group play, and having both [Down Time](/card/05033) and [Crew Quarters](/card/20029) for example are probably a bit overkill. As you add extra players, it may be helpful to diversify your portfolio, so see what works right for you. Definitely prioritise extra copies of [Endurance](/card/05023), [Plan B](/card/27024), and especially [Skilled Investigator](/card/04047) as you add more players.

![COLOSSUS](https://i.imgur.com/tpHQwSw.jpeg)
<font size="1">*Colossus still struggles with flirting but we believe one day he'll get the hang of it*</font>

name: SCL S13 R5 Spectrum Defends the Tower
description_md:
This is the deck to take on SCL Season 13, Round 5 against Export Tower Defense.

The goal is to get down [Mighty Avengers](/card/21015) and either [Command Team](/card/23016) and/or [Rapid Response](/card/08031), to get a few huge turns from one of three hard hitting allies: [Giant-Man](/card/12012), Power Man, or Goliath. [Make the Call](/card/01071) can help fish those friends out for when you need them.

The smaller allies are in there are blockers to help build the board up, especially since the villains can often attack twice a turn.  [Earth's Mightiest Heroes](/card/04022) can help ready either Spectrum or one of the bigger allies as well.   

If I had to do anything over again, I would have cut [Sneak Attack](/card/23017), since it was in there to cheat in a big ally... but that combo never showed up, given this is a bigger 50 card deck.

name: Nebulaus Overkill: No Quarter Loop
description_md: ------------------------------ **Intro:** ----------------- This is a One Turn Kill multiplayer deck that relies on a recursion of **[No Quarter](/card/28013)** and **[Looking for Trouble](/card/16043)** combined with **[Cutthroat Ambition](/card/16094)'s** ability to give **[Nebula](/card/16088)** overkill and piercing. Ever since **[No Quarter](/card/28013)** came out, I've wanted to make all Aggression deck that featured it and **[Honed Technique](/card/28017)**. I've also wanted to make an almost Infinite Loop deck like **KennedyHawk** made here **Ant-Man Resize Loop**. So, how do you get **[Nebula](/card/16088)** in a **[No Quarter](/card/28013)** Loop? There's a good amount of set-up involved. All of your Supports and Upgrades needs to be out. While that sounds like a lot, Nebula has enough to make it go relatively quickly. You'll be using **[Angela](/card/18011)** and **[Looking for Trouble](/card/16043)** to pull a minion, then **[No Quarter](/card/28013)** to kill it with overkill and piercing. Rinse, repeat. Until you deck out. Then do it again. Until the villain decks out. Then do it again. -------- ---------- **How to Set Up:** --------- - Set up your Aggression Supports and Upgrades your first run through your deck. Yes, every Aggression support or upgrade. Feel free to flip down to AE when the villain is confused to play a Nebula upgrade and draw two cards. Along with **[Nebula's Ship](/card/16093)**. - If you miss an upgrade or two, that's okay, you can get them on your second time through your deck. - Here's the important part: Second time through your deck, **do not let any Nebula upgrades go by without playing them. Once you play a Nebula upgrade, you have to flip down to AE, and stay there until all 8 Nebula upgrades are out.** - Now that all 8 Nebula upgrades are out you have overkill and piercing, +1 to Thwart and Attack, -2 damage from enemy attacks, retaliate 2, Stalwart, and can ignore guard, patrol and crisis. The ones we care about are overkill and piercing. ------------ **No Quarter Loop Sequence:** ------------- - Once you have all 8 upgrades out, use **[Hall of Heroes](/card/06017)** to get 3 cards. As long as you still have 2 No Quarters (or Angela) and 2 Looking For Troubles still in your hand or deck, you can start the loop. - So, the loop is play Looking For Trouble. Then attack the minion to get it down to the lowest HP possible without dying. Then play No Quarter for the highest amount you can. This will draw however many cards of excess damage you've done. - Eventually, you should get down to around 21 (Max of 24 or 25) cards to play each round. If you keep around 7 to 9 cards in your hand at all times, you'll be able to finish each deck run with a Looking for Trouble and No Quarter still in your hand. That will mean you need to average 6 or 7 excess damage to each minion that round. Since you can do at least 9 damage with Now Quarter and a maximum of 12, that shouldn't be that difficult. ------------------- **Tips to keep the sequence going:** ----------------------------- - **[Plan of Attack](/card/18013)** is key to maximizing each round. First, if you don't draw into a No Quarter, then use your **[Plan of Attack](/card/18013)s** to pull it. POA can also be used to pull your final No Quarter for the round, or to thin the deck and Grab **[Toe to Toe](/card/10015)**. Why **[Toe to Toe](/card/10015)**? - **[Angela](/card/18011)** is there in case you don't have a Looking For Trouble. You use her to get the minion, then **[Toe to Toe](/card/10015)** the villain to kill Angela after she defends for you, and get her back in your discard pile. - Use **[Battle Fury](/card/06018)** to ready Nebula, so she can attack minions if need be. If you're playing a villain with high HP minions, you can always add **[Combat Training](/card/01057)** to this deck. Then Nebula would hit for 5 if you count **[Unyielding Persistence](/card/16096)** and **[Fluid Motion](/card/28016)**. If you're playing low HP minions, you may not need to have Nebula attack. - Do not use **[Angela](/card/18011)** if you know there's only 1 minion left in the villain's deck. - Keep a count of how many minions the villain has. Once you've reached that limit, you know your next Looking for Trouble will just deck out the villain. Which is fine. That's why we have Angela as a back up. It's not 100%, but it should work with high minion villains like Drang, Zola, Green Goblin, Sentinels.. -------------------------- **Other Heroes That Can No Quarter Loop, Too:** ------------------------- - **[Iron Man](/card/01029a)** - He might do this sequence the smoothest. The problem is his excessive set-up time. Here's the deck I made for him: **Iron Man No Quarter Loop** The cool parts of him: He has so many ways to bring down minions with damage. You can actually get him down to 0 hero cards in your deck because **[Plan of Attack](/card/18013)** can pull both **[Repulsor Blast](/card/01031)** and **[Supersonic Punch](/card/01032)**. If for some reason, you're stuck with 5 cards, and don't want to deck with No Quarter? Just use **[Repulsor Blast](/card/01031)** to get rid of those 5 cards. End it all with a few 13 to 15 damage **[Dive Bomb](/card/17028)s**. - **[Star-Lord](/card/17001a)** - This deck **Star-Lord No Quarter Loop** gives encounter cards. Who's a fan of encounter cards? **[Star-Lord](/card/17001a)**. The issue is the math isn't perfect since he'll have 8 hero cards left. But if you get the sequence working, and you can end it with a couple 25+ damage **[Sliding Shot](/card/17005)s**? Amazing. - **[Black Widow](/card/01075)** and **[Ms. Marvel](/card/05001a)** probably can also make this work, but it went against my nature to have all of **[Black Widow](/card/01075)'s preparations** out but not use them ever. **[Ms. Marvel](/card/05001a)** should work, but I just couldn't get the sequence going. If someone else, can get her to do this deck, please publish it! ---------- **Questions:** - Q -Is this a lot of set up? Answer: Yes, it is. But I've never seen an OTK deck that didn't have a lot of set up. - Q - Can this be played solo? Answer: Not as an OTK deck, but as a deck that can use No Quarter, Honed Technique and Nebula's upgrades wisely, yes. Just add **[Professor X](/card/32019)** and **[Wolverine](/card/35001a)**, and she'll be ready to take on villains solo. - Q - Do you have any video of the loop sequence? Answer: No, but if someone wants to capture some, I'd be forever grateful. :)

name: Wolverine [Aggression] - It's Only a Flesh Wound
description_md:
Take advantage of Wolverine's incredible ability of paying for attack events with his *HIT POINTS*, as opposed to the conventional cost mechanic! Getting access to his attack event cards as quickly (and as frequently) as possible, and getting them into play so Wolvie can hack n' slash!!! Pretty straightforward deck, yet some of the following cards and combos are noteworthy in their significance, so let's talk about a few . . .

 - [Mean Swing](/card/06015) This card will serve you well on turns where you may not have attack event cards in your hand, and therefore wouldn't be exhausting his claws to pay for them using Wolverine's health. Exhaust his claws, and use this card to deal some decent damage! Cheap, and easy to play at 0 cost . . .

- [Moment of Triumph](/card/12030) This card should speak for itself. Wolverine will typically be sucking up a lot of damage in most games, (especially if you are using his health to pay for his attack cards), so this card is incredibly valuable. Helps keep you in hero form as long as possible so you don't lose tempo, and also pairs well with both [Skilled Strike](/card/09037) and [Mean Swing](/card/06015) when used on most minions. And if that isn't enough, follow up with an attack event to guarantee that excess damage, and heal up!!! Careful play of this card, coupled with Wolverine's natural healing ability, will keep you in the fight for a long time . . .

- [Plan of Attack](/card/18013) Helps you get those attack cards when you need them, thereby relying less on random card draw.

- [Clobber](/card/18012) This card pairs *so well* with Wolverine, it's almost sickening. Finding a good niche for this card by which to maximize it's utility previously was challenging, but not anymore . . . Pay for it first with Wolverine's health, then bounce it back into your hand. Repeat a 2nd time doing the same, or use it to pay for a more suitable ATT event depending on the circumstances. *INSANE* value for Wolverine!!!

TIPS/STRATEGIES:

I recently played in a multiplayer game, (which we won), where I didn't exhaust Wolverine ONE SINGLE TIME to defend against enemy attacks. Once you get [Endurance](/card/05023) and [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004) on the table, Wolverine's natural healing ability (every player phase), coupled with his high HP, will generally allow you to do this consistently. Keeps you ready to slash away and keep dealing damage during the Hero phases.  Consider "hard mulligans" to start the game with at least one of the above 2 cards, with [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004) being the priority.

Many of you will notice the absence of [The Power of Aggression](/card/01055) cards in here. If you look at the cost curve for AGG cards in this deck, you will see that they are simply not needed. The Basic double resource generators work just fine, and you'll generally be paying for the 3-cost attack cards with Wolvie's health anyways.

Lastly, you might try subbing in a few copies of [Ready to Rumble](/card/21022) for [Plan of Attack](/card/18013) if you feel more comfortable reverting back to alter-ego form more frequently. Try some different combos, and most importantly - have fun!!!

Enjoy,BUB!!!

name: Gamora is a Green Rushin
description_md:
Who knew protection is the best offense?  Gamora's strength comes from triggering Finesse and Precision as many times as possible.  Protection attack interrupts allow you to trigger on both phases about 70% of the time.  

[Keen Instincts](/card/18009) only pays for attack and thwart events so you need as many as possible.  [Impede](/card/18016) and [Clobber](/card/18012) start the round off with trigger events and then return to your hand to pay for the next one.

You will take some hits and need to flip down at least once.  Threat won't be a problem, but it is worth it to play [Conditioning Room](/card/18008).  This will guarantee you pop back with enough events to have a decisive turn.

name: Wolverine Hybrid Aggressor
description_md:
Inspired by both "'It's Clawberrin' Time!'" and "Fluid Adamantium," with this build I'm attempting to focus on rounding out the aggression playstyle, with both allies and events, all while building up the upgrades for the additive basic attack damages with [Adamantium Skeleton](/card/35004), [Combat Training](/card/01057) and a couple [Fluid Motion](/card/28016). These cards allow for a respectably obtainable +6 Basic Atk. That is before [Jubilee](/card/32088b), and some other additives included in the build.

But as mentioned in Clawberrin' Time, you gotta tank with allies. [Colossus](/card/32048) and [Angel](/card/33019) are our bodyguards here. [Colossus](/card/32048)' toughness and [Angel](/card/33019)'s cheapness are simple enough choices. The other allies are a bit more helpful in their specific actions. [Forge](/card/36022) can bring X-Jet or Utopia into hand. [Professor X](/card/37017) is the new OG. [Magik](/card/32042) and [Sunfire](/card/35014) both manipulate villainy. (Consider keeping [Thor](/card/13011) from the Clawberrin' Time deck for more tanking, but is a bit costly, especially as he won't benefit from Team-Building Exercise like the rest of the team).

With all of these allies tanking, Wolverine has health to spend [Wolverine's Claws](/card/35002) consistently on attack events. [Clobber](/card/18012) just feels right with Wolverine's Claws, putting it right back in hand at the cost of two health and freely igniting a [Fluid Motion](/card/28016). Though really, Wolverine's character specific attack event cards are absolutely solid for attack events so I'm not feeling the need to max out on aspect additions. 

Support is primarily focusing on supporting the Allies, with [Boot Camp](/card/13016), [Team-Building Exercise](/card/12024), and [Utopia](/card/33020). [Boot Camp](/card/13016) is not a priority, but will make a lot of these decent attacking allies all the better. Really [Utopia](/card/33020) and [Team-Building Exercise](/card/12024) are helping our X-Men game here.

Throw [Smash the Problem](/card/25019) and Wolverine's [Track by Scent](/card/35011) and we've got some decent scheme mitigation. Getting that +6 ATK turned into +6 THW for the cost of a single resource can be great. Combine with [Track by Scent](/card/35011) to play a lil engine.

[Honorary X-Men](/card/33035) is for my friend. Slap that on their hero for free, they gain the extra health, and access to Utopia and X-Jet if it's a better pay off for their use.

name: Captain Dive Bomber
description_md:
Goal of this deck is to play [Dive Bomb](/card/17028) w/ damage boosters such as [Honed Technique](/card/28017) and/or [Aggressive Energy](/card/32047).

[Plan of Attack](/card/18013) and [Assault Training](/card/26033) helps searches and recur [Dive Bomb](/card/17028). [No Quarter](/card/28013) can also be used to help dig for [Dive Bomb](/card/17028)

This deck is designed for multiplayer assuming another player is playing Protection. This deck does have [Hulk](/card/01050) and 2 other allies for meat shields. [Moment of Triumph](/card/12030) is also included for heals.

Ideal card combo is [Dive Bomb](/card/17028) + [Honed Technique](/card/28017) + [Aggressive Energy](/card/32047) for 12 damage to single enemy and 6 damage to other enemies.

name: Wasp Leadership Vs. Tower Defense SCL Season 13 Round 5
description_md:
This is the deck I played in Round 5 of Season 13 of the Solo Champions League vs. Tower Defense Expert with Streets of Mayhem as the modular.  Secret Lair was absolutely brutal in my games.  With such low threat thresholds to begin with on the two main schemes, having rounds start with 3 threat on each even after being cleared just took up a lot of time.  I was always hoping that a different environment would show up so Secret Lair would get replaced. 

All in all, I was happy with my results.  Kudos to those of you who managed to keep the Tower on the Stronghold side in all your games.  I wasn't able to do that.  Proxima's Power and Advances just typically hit at some point to flip the tower.  I did manage one official game where I got lucky and it didn't flip.  Other than that I was able to get clean boards, but the games were all LONG!

Game 1 - Win in 15 rounds.  Tower on Stronghold.  No threat left, no HP left on villains or minions and 16 health left between Wasp and allies. 

Game 2 - Win in 14 rounds.  Tower on Damaged.  No threat left, no HP left on villains or minions and 13 health left between Wasp and allies. 

Game 3 - Win in 13 rounds.  Tower on Damaged. No threat left, no HP left on villains or minions and 17 health left on Wasp and allies.  Actually used Nick Fury's ability to deal 4 damage upon entering play to seal the win and not have him take any damage.  

Final thoughts - Team Training was clutch for keeping allies out and also having max health left at the end. 

I wanted to get Iron Man out and put upgrades on him, but I just never was able to do that.  He was at the bottom of my deck in all my official games and I started putting stuff on other allies instead.

Probably should have included Make the Call.  Not sure why I didn't. 

Moxie and Ready To Rumble actually felt more useless than I expected.

name: SCL 1305 - Black Widow (L) vs Tower Defense + Streets of May
description_md: Deck for Solo Champions League Season 13, Round 5: * Round 5 - Tower Defense + Streets of Mayhem (01/22/23-02/04/23) * Difficulty: Expert * Hero: Ant-Man, Black Widow, Spectrum, Vision, or Wasp * Aspect: Leadership * Campaign Elements: + 3 Damage to Avengers Tower This deck was initially inspired by a Brian-V Sneak Attack deck, where the piece I really liked was abusing [Rapid Response](/card/08031) with Bucky and Dum Dum. So I shifted it to use [Regroup](/card/19032) (for White Tiger and cheap Bucky recursion) and here we are. Having the tower flip to the damaged side is a pretty big hit in hero score, so I went with Natasha, knowing that the games might be slow but that I could minimize my chances of having the tower flip. And this is exactly how it played out, with a nearly 13-turn average, but managing to keep the tower healthy every time. * **Game 1:** Pulled a double [Proxima's Power](/card/21106) on T2 when I flipped down to Alter-Ego, adding 3 damage to the tower because her main scheme popped. I then pulled [Sewer Tunnels](/card/24062) on T3 and it stuck around slowing me down until T14!. [Rain Fire](/card/21109) was too much of a threat to allow me to flip back to Alter-Ego for a long time, so I had to hide behind a [Grappling Hook](/card/08008) and [Target Acquired](/card/08024) to avoid the tower going to the damaged side. Finally won on T15 with a clean board, undamaged tower and 20 health on the hero side, but that was a slow game of patience. * **Game 2:** I was pinned down by [Sewer Tunnels](/card/24062) again for much of the game, but this time had the tower damage under control so could flip every turn. Won on turn 10 with a healthy tower, clean board and 14 HP on the hero side. [Dum Dum Dugan](/card/27047) did a serious amount of work on the last few turns, getting brought back by [Rapid Response](/card/08031) over and over again. * **Game 3:** 13 turn win with a healthy tower, clean board and 14 HP on the hero side. Saw an early [Rain Fire](/card/21109) that I couldn't cancel so only flipped to Alter-Ego when I needed to regenerate my [Grappling Hook](/card/08008).

name: Wolverine One Way or Another
description_md:
A [Wolverine](/card/35001a) Justice Deck that is built all around [One Way or Another](/card/22015) to draw cards and using cards like [Track by Scent](/card/35011) and [Clear the Area](/card/04049) to get rid of the side schemes that [One Way or Another](/card/22015) brings in. 

There is also [Overwatch](/card/30019) to help deal with the main scheme and is there are multiple schemes at once. 

Most of the Allies in this deck are high thwart like [Professor X](/card/32019), [Jessica Jones](/card/01059) (depending on how many sides schemes are in play), and [Quasar](/card/21047) can help with multiple schemes at once. [Wiccan](/card/15011) and [Jubilee](/card/35003) can help deal help damage and so can [Command Center](/card/35032).

name: Poker Night at S.H.I.E.L.D. Headquarters
description_md:
This is just the 'Playing Poker with Natasha Romanoff' deck, but I added a bunch of S.H.I.E.L.D. cards; it is now 50 cards because I am bad at removing things. The gimmick of the original is that you never leave alter ego throughout the entire game. I noticed the original deck tended to rack up too much threat without strong enough threat removal (at least in multiplayer), so my idea was to fix that by adding more threat removal in the form of powerful allies and Homeland Intervention.

The Field Agents are here to be exhausted for Global Logistics / Dum Dum Dugan / Homeland Intervention. As an added bonus, they can keep your heavy allies alive for a bit longer. Agent 13 can also ready them again.

Meditation seemed like a no-brainer to add, since you are always alter-ego and don't really exhaust Natasha otherwise. It also helps pay for the heavy allies and supports this deck has.

Global Logistics is mostly here to justify the 50 cards; you can use them to mill your own deck searching for setup cards (the Safe House / Black Widow's Gauntlet / Counterintelligence combo specifically). But it's also nice to be able to hit the encounter deck with them.

Edit 1: I replaced Beat Cops with Surveillance Team for more S.H.I.E.L.D. combos. I also dropped 1 copy of spycraft / counterintelligence and the Foiled! Event x3, so I could pick up Vigilante Training x2(to recycle Homeland Intervention), Team-Building Exercise (because Natasha has S.H.I.E.L.D. keyword), Monica Chang, and Sky-Destroyer.

Edit 2: Removed Team-building exercise because it's not playable as Natasha

name: Captain Marvel - Avengers leader
description_md: I build this deck to optimise Captain Marvel abilities with a lot of ressources. You can make crazy turns with a lot of cards draw with [Maria Hill](/card/01067), [Nick Fury](/card/01084), [Station Alpha Flight](/card/01015), [Manoir des Avengers](/card/01091) and Captain Marvel action. It's really fun to play. My favorite allies are [Maria Hill](/card/01067) (that you want to make her come back with [Appel de détresse](/card/01071)), [Vision](/card/01068) and [Goliath](/card/04013) that can make tons of damage with [État-Major](/card/23016). [Hawkeye](/card/04011) is not a really efficient way to use [Absorption d'Énergie](/card/01014) but when you don't have [Énergie Canalisée](/card/01018), it's still 3 damages with no consequential damages. I really love to use [Quinporteur](/card/08023) instead of [Héliporteur](/card/01092). It's a free heal + draw during each hero turn. It can also be use to add 2 damages for [Énergie Canalisée](/card/01018) without discarding a card. [Commander en Première Ligne](/card/01070) is not my favorite card of the deck. Can be situational but it grant us 3 ressources so it's still a good option to have it.

name: READY SMASH HULK (Get Up and Game!)
description_md:
I built this deck to rush down Rhino as fast as I could but it should work as a good rush deck against anyone. Basically just keep attacking and readying. Use Blade or Assess if you have leftover cards. 

Lockjaw can jump in and thwart if the game is dragging on. Spider-man is there for more damage but he can also jump in and thwart for 3 in a pinch. 

Momentum Shift and What Doesn’t Kill Me along with Endurance and Immovable Object should be enough to keep Hulk alive and in hero form long enough to win without needing to defend. 

You could bring in Unshakeable against villains with stuns. Also Return the Favor against villains that don’t get Tough or healing from their treacheries. Tackle is probably the card I would switch out for these.

name: Powers of X
description_md:
![Powers of X #6](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/58c35f74d1758e424ee76710/1570641686666-2XFUPOP4C66OAPHMMG7U/Powers+Of+X+6+cover.jpg?format=500w)


**Have you ever wanted to have a comic accurate X-Men reboot in Marvel Champions? Want to Create your own X-Men team and have them die multiple times? This deck is perfect for you.**

_
So far, this deck has won the Guardians and Mutant campaigns on Heroic as well Heroic Red Skull, Ultron, Green Goblin and more._

<hr>

## Powers of X:

The Goal of this deck is to have as many X-Men get killed by the Villain as you can. But don't worry this is the Marvel Universe, no one is ever really dead. A reboot is right around the corner. All you need is a little [Phoenix](/card/34001a) power and the [Tactical Brillance](/card/33010) to bring back the right X-Men.

<hr>

## Dawn of X:

The comics aren't going to let their characters stay dead and neither should you. The core of this deck is simple. Put your X-Men back into your hand with [Regroup](/card/19032) and play them again during your next turn. Kill Phoenix first during the villain phase so can grab [Tactical Brillance](/card/33010) which can in turn grab [Regroup](/card/19032). This means you can play any X-Men that are defeated every round so long as you have the resources. Resources aren't much of a problem if you have [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018) giving a discount for every single ally you play. These are the allies I used but X-Men allies can do almost anything so get to making your own team. If you need help here's a run down of X-Men doing whatever you could ask for.

<hr>

_**Have a annoying attachment anywhere?**_ [Sunfire](/card/35014) can get rid of it for you.

_**A minion you don't want to kill?**_ Send it to limbo with [Magik](/card/32042).

_**A side scheme?**_ [Storm](/card/34021) can remove 2 + move 2 threat from a side scheme and tactical brilliance can do 3. If you are playing in multiplayer and there is still threat left over, Cyclops + [Utopia](/card/33020) can do an extra 4.

_**Still need more threat removed?**_ Readying [Professor X](/card/32019) with [Utopia](/card/33020) can give you 6.

_**Want to confuse the Villain every round?**_ [Professor X](/card/32019) can handle it.

_**Want to ready Multiple X-Men?**_ [Professor X](/card/32019) + [Utopia](/card/33020) have got this too.

_**Need an cheap ally and/or an X-Men support in your hand?**_ [Forge](/card/36022) and [Angel](/card/33019) both only cost 1.

_**Does an Enemy have a pesky tough status card?**_ [Wolverine](/card/32041) has piercing.

_**Need to kill a lot of weak minions or Ultron Drones?**_ Use [Dust](/card/33012). Maybe even Twice.

_**Want a [Quincarrier](/card/08023) but you don't have the Avenger trait?**_ No need to worry, turn [Wolverine](/card/32041) into one with [Clarity of Purpose](/card/31029).

_**Want to confuse a minion?**_ That's easy for [Banshee](/card/34014) but since that's not usually worth it he's also got good basic power stats.

_**Want to look ahead in the encounter deck?**_ [Blindfold](/card/33014) will let you do that.

_**Do you need to damage a minion and thwart at the same time?**_ Seems like cheating but [Marvel Girl](/card/34015) does it anyway.

_**Are you trying to play lots of allies but don't have enough resources?**_ Play [Beast](/card/33011) and grab [Band Together](/card/21018) or any basic resources.

_**Is an Ally you need in the discard pile?**_ Good thing you have [Pixie](/card/36017). If you don't need the ally just use it as a resource.

[Nightcrawler](/card/32011). Yeah he single-handedly made me win when [Operation Zero Tolerance](/card/32104) was permanent. Use X-Jet to activate his Interrupt and then he only costs 2 to play again.

Why wouldn't you want [Polaris](/card/32012) and a tough card every round? Or Colossus' tough to take an attack? Or even two attacks if another player has [Hangar Bay](/card/36035).

_**Does the Villain have overkill?**_ Let Cyclops take the damage, he's not doing anything anyway. Or you could play [Rockslide](/card/33013) to retaliate and soak up lots of damage or extra minion attacks.

_**Are you trying to kill something?**_ Try [Havok](/card/36014) and [Gentle](/card/36016), they both have high ATK. 

[Mirage](/card/36015) can stun a minion. Maybe.

And [Longshot](/card/35033). I mean it's possible he kills the minion in one hit. Definitely possible.

<hr>

## The Deck:

You'll want at minimum 2 "resource" generators ([Team-Building Exercise](/card/12024), [Avengers Mansion](/card/01091), [The X-Jet](/card/32020), [Helicarrier](/card/01092), [Clarity of Purpose](/card/31029)) and [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018) before you start looping your X-Men by killing Phoenix. Use your allies to do a little thwarting and damage while you get your supports and then bring out the whole team when you are ready.

If you draw [Regroup](/card/19032) while resetting your hand, Congratulations, you don't have to pay for [Tactical Brillance](/card/33010) and kill [Phoenix](/card/33002) this villain phase.

If you need more cards on your turn put [Priority Target](/card/33007) on it and blast it with [Ruby Quartz Visor](/card/33003) to draw two cards.

[Cerebro](/card/34022) is here so [Forge](/card/36022) gives you a refund of resources if [The X-Jet](/card/32020) is already out.

_**Are you defending for other players all the time?**_ Use [Polaris](/card/32012), [Beast](/card/33011), 2 other cheap allies to be able to defend 6 attacks. And find a friend who will give you [Unflappable](/card/09020).

_**Do you need more THW/ATK per round?**_ Replace [Effective Leadership](/card/33018) and [Innovation](/card/21058) with [Lead from the Front](/card/01070) to bump up all of your ally powers.

_**Are you having trouble finding [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018)?**_ Just use three copies and use the extras as resources.

_**Do you want to play [White Tiger](/card/21013) from your hand every round?**_ Go ahead but you wont get the discount from [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018) or the Ally Limit increase from [Utopia](/card/33020).

_**Playing Multiplayer?**_ Don't let your friends play Phoenix. But you can let them play [Boot Camp](/card/13016), [Unflappable](/card/09020), [Hangar Bay](/card/36035), [Sense of Justice](/card/14030), or [Heroic Intuition](/card/01065) on you in exchange for you doing anything they could ask. Regroup works for all the allies on the table so the other players will get their allies back as well.

_**Want to cancel [Shadow of the Past](/card/01190)? or [Cruel Intentions](/card/24029)**_ I got nothing. I did say almost anything didn't I?

name: Made of X-Ally Colossus Leadership
description_md:
(_first thing first : excuse my english as it is not my native language, feel free to point me out any grammar or idiomatic mistake that would lead to a misunderstanding _)

This deck is best suited for solo games as it uses a lot -if not most- of the X-MEN basic allies.

The first idea is to acknowledge that Colossus' cards are **very powerful although inexpensive**, Colossus' events in particular . 
As the leadership affinity does not lean too much toward dealing with events cards, it is the place to be for this general principle :
**build up a powerful stronghold of allies to allow Colossus to maintain his tough status cards as long as possible**

[Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018) is your top priority card, you shall mulligan hard to find it. It will reduce the cost by 1 of any X-Men ally when you would swap to [Colossus](/card/32001a), just like that! You would be tempted to add another [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018) to the deck it is up to you.

[Weapon X](/card/35022) and [Piotr's Studio](/card/32003) will make this deck mills a lot of your cards, most importantly **X-men allies** that you would return to play with [Make the Call](/card/01071).

That goes without saying that allies are kind of your "tough cards status" , moreover defeated allies combine with [Rapid Response](/card/08031) allows some lucrative moves. The best combo would be [Rapid Response](/card/08031) + [Beast](/card/33011). This should be played any time possible.

Note that there are only two non-Xmen allies :
 
1.[Nick Fury](/card/01084): it combines well with [Rapid Response](/card/08031), most of time I suggest to draw 3 cards.

2.[Machine Man](/card/26022): sometimes you will find yourself with a lot of ressource that you wouldn't know what to do with them ;-)

These 2 allies should be the first targeted by villain attacks to assure you they don't mess too much with [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018) and [Utopia](/card/33020). These allies are to some extent situational.





It is all about tempo here, you decide which ally you want to die or you decide whether you want to loose one if not all your tough status cards and draw with #Iron Will, bring them back this [Organic Steel](/card/32006) if you can. Stun and Confuse every time you can with [Steel Fist](/card/32008)[Mirage](/card/36015) and[Professor X](/card/32019); get Colossus ready with [Utopia](/card/33020)and [Bulletproof Protector](/card/32009). 

Step by step you will build a pretty solid stronghold of allies + your 2 tough status card; in some scenario you won't even feel the need to heal your identity.

Lastly Piot Rasputin's power will assure you to bring back Colossus cards in the deck and [Piotr's Studio](/card/32003) + [Weapon X](/card/35022) to your hand. 

Some cards you could add?

+1 [Team Training](/card/04016) : in addition to be less expensive with [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018) X-men allies would live longer giving them +2 hit points in total!

+1 [The Power of Leadership](/card/01072)

+1 #The Power in All of Us 

a 2nd [Uncanny X-Men](/card/36018)

name: Doctor Strange - The Doctor is in
description_md:
As Seen on [Late Night Gaming](https://youtu.be/SPKk6BiJJ_w)

DOCTOR STRANGE

Very strong hero, with really well built theme with the hero kit. Doctor Strange is the one you use when you really want to feel like the hero you’re using.

THE BUILD
This set up is so that you can both defend and ready yourself and your Allie’s through the use of various cards. 
First up we are running 3 [Ever Vigilant](/card/17030), for that sweet thwart and ready combo, allowing strange to be able to exhaust and utilize an invocation. There is also 3 [Desperate Defense](/card/09015)and 3 [What Doesn't Kill Me](/card/27016), for the same purpose. 
On the ally side we’re running 1 [Hangar Bay](/card/36035) so once you place a tough status on your ally through your invocation you will be able to defend and ready that ally for use the next turn. This is especially awesome when used with [Wong](/card/09002), as you’ll get the opportunity to exhaust him and cycle an invocation that you don’t want to use. [Team-Building Exercise](/card/12024) is here to aid in getting any of the Allie’s into play, as well as reducing the cost of [Ever Vigilant](/card/17030) as when you can use it, you’d have the aerial trait from [Cloak of Levitation](/card/09009).

So have some fun being DR Strange and control everything the villain throws at you!

name: $$$ Big Money Colossus $$$

name: Mind Over Matter
description_md:
**[Vision](/card/01068)** is a top tier Voltron target, oft-overlooked for more flexible options with less of a ceiling. This deck is all about unleashing his maximum potential! We load up [Vision](/card/01068) with some matter, unleash him with Phoenix's mind, and whip up some brilliant tactical play! *They even have the same color scheme*
A fully kitted [Vision](/card/01068) hits **6 ATK, 3 THW, and 8 HP** (counting [Power Gloves](/card/12017) as ATK for simplicity here). Add in his ability and he can hit **8/5**, while [Psychic Kicker](/card/34034) gets him to **10/7** for a single activation. [Reboot](/card/26024) and [Game Time](/card/33022) give him a free activation, while [Psychic Kicker](/card/34034) and [Sky Cycle](/card/04015) are offset by healing in the form of [Innovation](/card/21058), [First Aid](/card/01086), and [X-Mansion](/card/32049). The endgame ceiling here is 8 ATK Vision that can activate 8 times, with x3 [Psychic Kicker](/card/34034), x3 [Game Time](/card/33022)/[Reboot](/card/26024), and [Sky Cycle](/card/04015). **This is 70 damage!** Add in attacks from Unleashed Phoenix and [Cyclops](/card/34003) (or a potentially [Mind Control](/card/34009)'d minion) and the maximum damage in a single turn is 75+!
## **Game Flow** - Early game focus on getting out [White Hot Room](/card/34004), [The X-Jet](/card/32020), [X-Mansion](/card/32049) - Phoenix will need to tank a lot of hits to the face, so the heal from **[White Hot Room](/card/34004)** and [X-Mansion](/card/32049) are welcome to keep her from exhausting so she can spam her 3 THW wherever possible. She'll be flipping most turns, but **[Telekinetic Shield](/card/34007)** can help keep her in hero for two turns if necessary - Get out [Vision](/card/01068) normally or search for him with **[Call for Aid](/card/12015)** when ready - Start kitting him up, especially prioritizing **[Honorary X-Men](/card/33035)** so that he gets +1 hp, access to **[X-Mansion](/card/32049)** healing, and **[Danger Room Training](/card/33015)** - Upgrades can be prioritized on game state: usually health is first if he doesn't have [Honorary X-Men](/card/33035) yet. Damage is good because Phoenix will be covering a lot of thwart; being able to split a damage off with **[Power Gloves](/card/12017)** is great, especially after a thwart, pinging toughs before readying to one-shot the target or pinging the tough off the next villain stage when defeating the first!; [Sidearm](/card/23035) is great for retaliate matches - Use power counters, **[The X-Jet](/card/32020)**, and **[Innovation](/card/21058)** to trigger his ability every turn - Use [White Hot Room](/card/34004) and basic recoveries to keep enough power counters on [Phoenix Force A](/card/34002a) to be able to keep triggering [Vision](/card/01068) every turn - Set up some 50+ damage turns and win!
## **Mental Notes** - [Vision](/card/01068) is a great counter to **[Dark Phoenix](/card/34029)**, most of the times when she comes out, he can 2 or 3-hit her back to where she came from depending on if her tough gets cleared by something else. Dropping [Dark Phoenix](/card/34029) for 0-1 resource cost is huge! - Sometimes [Vision](/card/01068) will need to be played and used up early, just to stabilize the board state, then get fully Voltron'd on the second deck pass. [Cyclops](/card/34003) can be a great temporary Voltron with [Danger Room Training](/card/33015) if [Vision](/card/01068) doesn't have [Honorary X-Men](/card/33035) yet - [Game Time](/card/33022) and [Psychic Kicker](/card/34034) are hero actions, but [Reboot](/card/26024) and [Vision](/card/01068)'s triggers aren't, which can allow Phoenix to stay a Jean Grey for an extra turn, with [Vision](/card/01068) **handling things from alter-ego**! - **No double resources!** Aside from [Vision](/card/01068) and our four supports, we will pretty much never be playing anything other than 0- or 1-cost upgrades that play to [Vision](/card/01068) or events that ready [Vision](/card/01068). With plenty of alter-ego turns and 2 extra resources per turn from power counters and [The X-Jet](/card/32020), we have no problem affording what we need to! - [Vision](/card/01068) does not need to survive the game to win. Health upgrades are important early to keep him out until the endgame, yet if you have three readies available and enough damage to win but [Vision](/card/01068) spends his last hp in the process, do it! **Checkmate ends the game!** - I did win (and lose) some solo games with this. With careful play and good risk-reward decision making it can overcome that initial solo curve. However, **I primarily see this as a multiplayer deck**. In my 2-player games, [Vision](/card/01068) really sings. In solo, he one-shots most side schemes and minions ...but he does that in 2-player as well! In a 2-player Expert Mansion Attack game, [Vision](/card/01068) took out the last 2 Brotherhood of Mutants villains in a single phase! - Managing [Vision](/card/01068)'s matter-state is the key to success here. **Knowing when to spend health and when to conserve it is a central decision point, hence "mind over matter!" **If the board is clear, but I don't have lethal, I'll refrain from hitting the villain just to save [Vision](/card/01068)'s hp. Sometimes [Game Time](/card/33022) and [Reboot](/card/26024) are used just for the heals. This deck will take a few plays to gain familiarity with this kind of tempo. It will test your player skill! The greater the difficulty to mastery, the greater the reward!
Good luck!

name: The Evil Witch!
description_md:
Welcome Champions! Have you ever wanted a sort of PVP in Champions? Or did your gaming buddy take the last soda so now you want some sweet revenge? Well than this is the deck for you!

[Scarlet Witch](/card/15001a) has been famous since release for her ability to burn through the encounter deck at an astounding pace. This deck takes that and pushes it to the max, but NOT for the other player's benefit. You see, this Wanda is the real mastermind behind the villain's plan... 

The wording on the cards really matters, with the differentiation between who a card can affect is pretty huge. Consider [Hex Bolt](/card/15004). Mostly the 3+ boost effect. Usually one would stun/confuse an enemy or give a friend a tough. However, evil Wanda doesn't want that: she wants her Villain puppet to defeat the other pesky heroes! Stun and Confuse your fellow heroes to slow them down, or give the villain a tough! 
(This wording also lets her heal the villain with [First Aid](/card/01086))

[One Way or Another](/card/22015) is usually used to pull a weak side scheme for some easy scheme-cleaning rewards. But with this Witch, we can pull the most devastating side scheme for the heroes to try and beat. (Bonus points for confusing them first!)

Wanda's power allow her some forms of mind control, as the usual good guy [Agent Coulson](/card/08011) helps her diabolical plans! He can pull out a [Spycraft](/card/08018) to mill through the weaker encounter cards and pull a truly nasty side scheme for our friends to deal with, or to keep Wanda safe from her puppet breaking free of her control! Keep Coulson out, he's what let's you play those [Spycraft](/card/08018)s!

The valiant [Heimdall](/card/06020) has also fallen to the Witch's side! Use him to mill through the encounter deck, block villain attacks, and to destroy any minions who dare attack the true evil mastermind! [Blindfold](/card/33014) also helps with this.

The [Field Agent](/card/27044) and [Helicarrier](/card/01092), along with Coulson, are to trigger [Global Logistics](/card/27043). Use these to discard four cards from a hero's deck, or to set up a devastating array of treacheries and minions! [Shadow of the Past](/card/01190) can be devastating, especially when delivered at a pivotal moment!

Venom and [Symbiote Suit](/card/27191) are here to hand out more encounter cards, and the [Pulse Grenade](/card/17023)s will help you mill that encounter deck faster!

Finally, [Scarlet Witch's Crest](/card/15009), along side of her hero ability, lets us boost the power of the villain's activation!

There you have it, this is the Evil [Scarlet Witch](/card/15001a). Enjoy!
